    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your poem. I‚Äôll focus on improving word choice, capitalization, punctuation, and tense consistency while preserving your line breaks, imagery, and free-verse feel. Before I propose a final edited version, a couple of quick questions to make sure my edits match your intent:
- Do you want a consistent lowercase style (including ‚Äúi‚Äù), or standard capitalization throughout? Your current poem mixes both.
- Are you open to small tense tweaks to keep the poem present-focused?
- Do you prefer parentheses for asides, or would you like to use em dashes for a more seamless, lyrical flow?

Overview of the editorial approach
- Correct the single spelling error.
- Smooth tense consistency so the poem stays present-focused.
- Suggest a consistent capitalization approach (either all-lowercase for a lyrical, contemplative tone or standard capitalization for a more formal journal style).
- Offer subtle punctuation adjustments (em dashes vs commas/parentheses) to enhance cadence.
- Provide optional word-choice refinements that keep your metaphors intact.
- Offer an optional stanza break to heighten the emotional turn.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
- Line 1: ‚Äúthe sun dropps behind the hill‚Äî‚Äù
  - Change ‚Äúdropps‚Äù to ‚Äúdrops‚Äù (spelling).
  - Keep the em dash; it works well as a lingering pause and sets the contemplative tone.
  - Capitalization choice: if you go all-lowercase, this line is already aligned.

- Line 2: ‚Äúi chase the day like a late bus,‚Äù
  - This line reads well. The simile is vivid and contemporary.
  - Capitalization choice: keep ‚Äúi‚Äù lowercase if you choose the all-lowercase style; otherwise change to ‚ÄúI.‚Äù

- Line 3: ‚Äúshoes unlaced, the gravel keeps my secrets.‚Äù
  - The comma works, but consider an em dash for a more lyrical hinge: ‚Äúshoes unlaced‚Äîthe gravel keeps my secrets.‚Äù
  - Reason: the dash strengthens the connection and adds a musical pause. The phrase ‚Äúkeeps my secrets‚Äù is strong; if you want a tactile nuance, ‚Äúholds‚Äù is an option, but ‚Äúkeeps‚Äù maintains the confidentiality image.

- Line 4: ‚ÄúI call the trees my witnesses‚Äù
  - For capitalization consistency, use either ‚Äúi‚Äù (if all-lowercase) or keep ‚ÄúI‚Äù and adjust earlier lines to standard case.
  - Optional word choice: ‚Äúname the trees my witnesses‚Äù is slightly more formal/ceremonial; ‚Äúcall‚Äù is more conversational. Choose based on the tone you want.

- Line 5: ‚Äúand they don‚Äôt answer (they never did)‚Äù
  - Tense consistency: change ‚Äúdid‚Äù to ‚Äúdo‚Äù to keep the poem in the present: ‚Äúand they don‚Äôt answer (they never do).‚Äù
  - If you prefer a seamless flow, consider an em dash instead of parentheses: ‚Äúand they don‚Äôt answer‚Äî they never do.‚Äù Parentheses feel more self-aware; em dashes feel more embedded in the voice.

- Line 6: ‚Äúbut the leaves clap anyway, a small stadium.‚Äù
  - Consider an em dash to clarify the apposition: ‚Äúbut the leaves clap anyway‚Äîa small stadium.‚Äù
  - Reason: the dash emphasizes ‚Äúa small stadium‚Äù as a metaphorical rename rather than a loose addition. If you prefer a simile, ‚Äúlike a small stadium‚Äù is also clear, but the metaphor is stronger as-is.

- Line 7: ‚Äútomorrow is a folded map in my pocket‚Äù
  - Strong image; reads clearly. No changes needed.
  - If you adopt standard capitalization, capitalize ‚ÄúTomorrow.‚Äù

- Line 8: ‚Äúthat I forgot to unfold.‚Äù
  - Tense consistency: shift to present perfect for cohesion with the rest of the poem: ‚Äúthat I haven‚Äôt yet unfolded.‚Äù
  - If you prefer a more direct phrasing, you can end the poem with an em dash for a quiet, suspended feeling:
    - ‚Äúthat I haven‚Äôt yet unfolded‚Äî‚Äù
    - Or add the pronoun for clarity: ‚Äúthat I haven‚Äôt yet unfolded it.‚Äù (This slightly reduces the elegance; the noun ‚Äúmap‚Äù already carries the action.)

Overall Feedback
- Strengths: Your imagery is vivid and coherent‚Äîthe late bus, witnesses of trees, stadium of leaves, and the folded map work together as a persuasive meditation on urgency and intention. Sound devices like ‚Äúshoes,‚Äù ‚Äúsecrets,‚Äù and ‚Äústadium‚Äù give the poem soft consonance. The em dash in line 1 sets a reflective pace that suits the lyrical tone.
- Main improvements: Correct the spelling error, unify capitalization, and maintain present-tense consistency. A few punctuation adjustments can heighten the rhythm and clarity without changing your metaphors.

Spelling Edits
- ‚Äúdropps‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúdrops‚Äù
  - Reason: Standard spelling.

Grammar Edits
- Tense consistency:
  - ‚Äú(they never did)‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äú(they never do)‚Äù to keep present tense across the poem.
  - ‚Äúthat I forgot to unfold‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúthat I haven‚Äôt yet unfolded‚Äù to align with present-focused narration.
- Capitalization consistency:
  - Choose one of the following:
    - All-lowercase style for a contemplative, modern feel: ‚Äúi‚Äù throughout; keep line-initial words lowercase.
    - Standard capitalization for literary journal formality: Capitalize ‚ÄúThe,‚Äù ‚ÄúI,‚Äù ‚ÄúTomorrow,‚Äù and sentence beginnings.

Structural Suggestions
- Consider a stanza break after line 6 to separate the external scene (chasing day, trees, leaves) from the inward turn (tomorrow as a map). For example:
  - Stanza 1: lines 1‚Äì6
  - Stanza 2: lines 7‚Äì8
  - Reason: It creates a clean pivot from witness/response to intention/future.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Punctuation cadence:
  - Line 3: Em dash instead of comma can strengthen the hinge between action and secrecy.
  - Line 6: Em dash before ‚Äúa small stadium‚Äù clarifies apposition and heightens the image.
- Optional word-choice refinements (only if desired):
  - ‚Äúcall‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúname‚Äù for a ceremonial tone.
  - ‚Äúkeeps‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúholds‚Äù for tactile resonance. These are stylistic, not necessary.

Formatting Guidance
- Em dashes: Use a true em dash (‚Äî) with no surrounding spaces for a clean, contemporary look, as you‚Äôve done in line 1. If you add more dashes, keep that convention consistent.
- Parenthetical aside vs em dash: Parentheses create a thoughtful whisper; em dashes integrate the aside into the line‚Äôs flow. Either is acceptable‚Äîchoose one style and apply it consistently.
- Capitalization:
  - All-lowercase is an accepted poetry convention and suits a contemplative tone; ensure ‚Äúi‚Äù is consistently lowercase if you choose this.
  - If the journal favors standard capitalization, use sentence case for lines that form complete sentences.
- Line breaks: Your current breaks work well and should be preserved. If you add a stanza break after line 6, insert one blank line between stanzas.

Would you like me to generate the edited poem? I can provide:
- Version A: all-lowercase with em dashes (contemplative style).
- Version B: standard capitalization with either em dashes or parentheses (more formal journal style).

If you have a preference on parentheses vs em dashes and capitalization style, tell me which you‚Äôd like, and I‚Äôll produce the polished version accordingly."

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your draft and clear goals. I‚Äôll help clarify your thesis and evaluation criteria, fix grammar and tone, suggest a structure (intro‚Äìsummary‚Äìanalysis‚Äìconclusion), and give MLA formatting guidance for book titles and quotes‚Äîall while avoiding spoilers beyond the mid-point.

Overview of the editorial plan
- Sharpen the thesis to state your overall evaluation and the criteria you‚Äôll use (symbolism, pacing, thematic depth).
- Adjust tone toward analytical yet accessible (less ‚ÄúI liked,‚Äù more ‚ÄúLowry uses...‚Äù).
- Clean up grammar and punctuation for clarity and flow.
- Propose a clear four-part structure: introduction, brief summary (early plot only), analysis, conclusion.
- Show you how to format titles and quotes in MLA and recommend citation practices.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
1) Original: ‚ÄúIn The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community seems perfect but actually its not.‚Äù
   - Suggested revision: ‚ÄúIn The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community appears perfect, but it is not.‚Äù
   - Reasoning:
     - ‚Äúits‚Äù should be ‚Äúit‚Äôs‚Äù or ‚Äúit is‚Äù; choosing ‚Äúit is‚Äù keeps a formal tone.
     - ‚Äúseems‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúappears‚Äù is a more analytical verb.
     - Add a comma before the coordinating conjunction ‚Äúbut‚Äù to separate independent clauses.
     - This sentence can also serve your thesis if expanded: it sets up the book‚Äôs central tension.

   Optional stronger thesis version:
   - ‚ÄúIn The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community appears perfect, but the novel reveals the hidden costs of sameness; through color symbolism, measured pacing, and an ambiguous ending, Lowry invites readers to question the price of safety.‚Äù

2) Original: ‚ÄúI liked the way the author use color as a symbol of freedom and choice.‚Äù
   - Suggested revision: ‚ÄúLowry uses color as a symbol of freedom and choice.‚Äù
   - Reasoning:
     - Subject‚Äìverb agreement: ‚Äúauthor use‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúauthor uses.‚Äù
     - Shift from personal reaction (‚ÄúI liked‚Äù) to analytical claim, which strengthens your tone.
     - Naming the author adds clarity and authority.

3) Original: ‚ÄúWhen Jonas first sees the apple ‚Äòchange,‚Äô it foreshadows him seeing the world differently.‚Äù
   - Suggested revision: ‚ÄúWhen Jonas first notices the apple ‚Äòchange,‚Äô it foreshadows his changing perception of the world.‚Äù
   - Reasoning:
     - ‚Äúsees‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúnotices‚Äù is more precise.
     - Replace ‚Äúhim seeing the world differently‚Äù with ‚Äúhis changing perception of the world‚Äù for concision and formality.
     - Keep the quoted word; it‚Äôs an early-text detail, avoiding later spoilers.
     - Consider a signal phrase for MLA style (e.g., ‚ÄúEarly in the novel, Jonas notices the apple ‚Äòchange‚Äô...‚Äù).

4) Original: ‚ÄúThe pacing in the middle got slow for me and I think the ending was confusing but good.‚Äù
   - Suggested revision: ‚ÄúThe pacing slows in the middle, and the ending is ambiguous yet effective.‚Äù
   - Reasoning:
     - Remove ‚Äúfor me‚Äù and ‚ÄúI think‚Äù to maintain analytical tone.
     - ‚Äúconfusing but good‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúambiguous yet effective‚Äù is more precise and academic.
     - Add a comma before ‚Äúand‚Äù to join independent clauses clearly.

5) Original: ‚ÄúOverall I would recommend this book because it makes you think about choices and memory and what is price of safety.‚Äù
   - Suggested revision: ‚ÄúOverall, I recommend this book because it prompts reflection on choices, memory, and the price of safety.‚Äù
   - Reasoning:
     - Add a comma after ‚ÄúOverall‚Äù (introductory word).
     - Parallel structure: ‚Äúchoices, memory, and the price of safety.‚Äù
     - ‚Äúmakes you think‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúprompts reflection‚Äù is more formal.

Spelling edits (with explanations)
- ‚Äúits‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúit is‚Äù or ‚Äúit‚Äôs‚Äù: ‚Äúits‚Äù is possessive; you need the contraction or full verb phrase.
- No other spelling errors detected.

Grammar edits (with explanations)
- Subject‚Äìverb agreement: ‚Äúauthor use‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúauthor uses.‚Äù
- Commas:
  - After introductory words: ‚ÄúOverall,‚Äù
  - Between independent clauses: ‚Äúappears perfect, but it is not.‚Äù
- Parallelism: ‚Äúchoices and memory and what is price of safety‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúchoices, memory, and the price of safety.‚Äù
- Precision and concision: ‚Äúhim seeing the world differently‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúhis changing perception of the world.‚Äù

Structural suggestions (intro‚Äìsummary‚Äìanalysis‚Äìconclusion)
- Introduction (1 paragraph):
  - Present the book and author (italicize the title in your final draft).
  - State a clear thesis that includes your evaluation and criteria (symbolism, pacing, ending).
- Summary (1 short paragraph, early plot only):
  - Briefly describe the setup: Jonas‚Äôs community and early signs of change (e.g., the apple ‚Äúchange‚Äù moment).
  - Avoid details beyond the mid-point.
- Analysis (1‚Äì2 paragraphs):
  - Symbolism: Explain how color represents freedom and choice; connect to themes of memory and moral responsibility.
  - Pacing: Discuss how the mid-book slowdown affects tension and how it may mirror the community‚Äôs monotony.
  - Ending: Characterize it as ambiguous and thought-provoking without describing late events.
- Conclusion (1 paragraph):
  - Restate your thesis in light of the analysis.
  - Give a clear recommendation tailored to classmates/teacher and the kind of reader who would appreciate the book.

Opportunities for improvement
- Define evaluation criteria explicitly in the intro (symbolism, pacing, thematic depth), then return to each in analysis.
- Add one more piece of textual evidence (another brief quote from early chapters) to support the symbolism point.
- Use topic sentences to guide readers: begin analysis paragraphs with clear claims.
- Strengthen transitions: ‚ÄúThis symbolism underscores...,‚Äù ‚ÄúIn contrast, the pacing...‚Äù
- Refine diction for academic tone: ‚Äúappears,‚Äù ‚Äúsuggests,‚Äù ‚Äúunderscores,‚Äù ‚Äúinvites readers.‚Äù

Formatting guidance (MLA for titles and quotes)
- Book title: Italicize The Giver wherever it appears in your final draft.
- Quotes:
  - Use double quotation marks for quoted words or short phrases: ‚Äúchange.‚Äù
  - Integrate quotes with a signal phrase: ‚ÄúEarly in the novel, Jonas notices the apple ‚Äòchange‚Äô...‚Äù
  - If your edition has page numbers and your teacher requires them, add a parenthetical citation after the quote: ‚Äúchange‚Äù (Lowry 23). If you name Lowry in the sentence, you may include only the page number (23).
- Works Cited (example format; confirm your edition details):
  - Lowry, Lois. The Giver. Houghton Mifflin, 1993.
- General MLA:
  - Double-space; 1-inch margins; Times New Roman 12 pt.
  - Include your name, instructor, course, date (top left), and a centered title.
  - Indent paragraphs by 0.5 inches.

Would you like a full rewrite?
Below is a concise, structured revision incorporating the edits and one quote, with no spoilers beyond the mid-point. If you want a longer version (400‚Äì600 words), I can expand it.

Draft revision (apply italics to the book title in your final document):
Introduction:
In The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community appears perfect, but the novel reveals the hidden costs of sameness. Evaluating the book‚Äôs symbolism, pacing, and thematic depth, I argue that Lowry‚Äôs use of color powerfully represents freedom and choice, the mid-book pacing reduces urgency, and the ending‚Äîthough ambiguous‚Äîinvites thoughtful discussion.

Summary (early plot only):
Jonas lives in an orderly society designed to eliminate conflict and difference. Early in the novel, he notices an apple ‚Äúchange,‚Äù a moment that foreshadows his changing perception of the world and hints that not everything in his community is what it seems.

Analysis:
Color functions as a symbol of individuality and possibility, contrasting with the community‚Äôs uniform uniformity. As Jonas‚Äôs perceptions broaden, Lowry suggests that true choice requires the ability to perceive differences, linking the novel‚Äôs exploration of memory to moral responsibility. While the middle sections slow, the measured pacing mirrors the community‚Äôs controlled routine and emphasizes how difficult it is to disrupt a system built on predictability.

Conclusion:
Although the ending resists a tidy resolution, its openness is effective because it pushes readers to consider what safety costs and who pays that price. Overall, I recommend The Giver because it prompts reflection on choices, memory, and the price of safety.

Would you like me to:
- Expand the analysis with one more early-text quote?
- Add MLA in-text citations with page numbers from your edition?
- Format a complete Works Cited section based on your edition details?"

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your excerpt and your goals. I‚Äôll provide line-by-line edits with reasoning, structural suggestions to sharpen your argument, and Chicago Notes-Bibliography formatting guidance. I‚Äôll keep your footnote markers [1], [2] as placeholders and won‚Äôt add sources.

Quick clarifying question:
- Is this paragraph an intro to a larger section or a standalone conclusion to a subsection? That affects how strongly the thesis needs to signal the section‚Äôs scope and how much synthesis is needed at the end.

Overview of the editorial approach:
- Tighten the thesis for clarity and flow.
- Improve sentence-to-sentence coherence and transitions.
- Correct grammar issues (subject‚Äìverb agreement, tense consistency, wordiness).
- Refine diction for a formal, objective tone.
- Provide Chicago NB footnote and formatting pointers.
- Offer a clean revised version you can drop in.

Categorized feedback

Overall Feedback
- Your thesis is strong: it clearly distinguishes outcomes (did not end the Depression) from significance (redefined citizen‚Äìstate relations).
- The two examples (CCC and domestic worker exclusions) support the theme of ‚Äúlimits and contradictions.‚Äù Strengthen the bridge back to your thesis with a concluding sentence that synthesizes how these examples illustrate the broader claim.
- Main improvements: tighten phrasing, maintain past tense, improve precision (e.g., ‚Äúaffected‚Äù vs. ‚Äúimpacted‚Äù), and clarify the relationship between examples and the overarching argument.

Spelling Edits
- No spelling errors detected.
- Optional diction refinement:
  - Replace ‚Äúimpacted‚Äù with ‚Äúaffected‚Äù for more formal tone.

Grammar Edits (line-by-line, with reasoning)
1) Original: ‚ÄúThe New Deal did not end the Great Depression; however, it redefined the relationship between citizens and the federal government.‚Äù
   - Edit: ‚ÄúAlthough the New Deal did not end the Great Depression, it redefined the relationship between citizens and the federal government.‚Äù
   - Reason: Replacing ‚Äú; however,‚Äù with ‚ÄúAlthough ‚Ä¶‚Äù makes the sentence smoother and avoids a heavy mid-sentence pause. This also strengthens the causal/contrast relationship.

2) Original: ‚ÄúRelief agencies were criticized as being both too much and not enough.‚Äù
   - Edit: ‚ÄúRelief agencies faced criticism for being simultaneously excessive and insufficient.‚Äù
   - Reason: Removes the wordy ‚Äúas being,‚Äù replaces colloquial phrasing (‚Äútoo much and not enough‚Äù) with concise formal language, and keeps past tense.

3) Original: ‚ÄúFor example, the CCC created jobs for young men but also reinforced certain gender norms.[1]‚Äù
   - Edit: ‚ÄúFor example, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) created jobs for young men but reinforced prevailing gender norms.[1]‚Äù
   - Reason: On first mention, spell out the acronym for clarity; ‚Äúprevailing‚Äù is more precise than ‚Äúcertain‚Äù; deleting ‚Äúalso‚Äù tightens the sentence without changing meaning.

4) Original: ‚ÄúIn addition, some programs excluded domestic workers, which disproportionately impacted Black women.[2]‚Äù
   - Edit: ‚ÄúAdditionally, some programs excluded domestic workers, a policy that disproportionately affected Black women.[2]‚Äù
   - Reason: ‚ÄúAdditionally‚Äù is slightly tighter than ‚ÄúIn addition,‚Äù ‚Äúaffected‚Äù is more formal than ‚Äúimpacted,‚Äù and changing the relative clause (‚Äúwhich‚Äù) to ‚Äúa policy that‚Äù clarifies the referent (the exclusion itself) and improves flow.

5) Original: ‚ÄúWhile the scope of reform was unprecedented, the policies had limits that shows the contradictions of the era.‚Äù
   - Edit: ‚ÄúWhile the scope of reform was unprecedented, these policies had limits that revealed the era‚Äôs contradictions.‚Äù
   - Reason: Fixes subject‚Äìverb agreement (‚Äúpolicies ‚Ä¶ revealed,‚Äù not ‚Äúshows‚Äù), maintains past tense, and strengthens the verb (‚Äúrevealed‚Äù instead of ‚Äúshowed‚Äù) for analytical tone.

Structural Suggestions
- Keep the current sequence (thesis ‚Üí general criticism ‚Üí example 1 ‚Üí example 2 ‚Üí synthesis), but:
  - Strengthen the final sentence to explicitly connect the examples to the thesis (how they demonstrate the redefinition‚Äôs limits).
  - Consider a brief bridge phrase at the start of the concluding sentence (e.g., ‚ÄúTaken together,‚Äù or ‚ÄúThese mixed outcomes‚Äù) to make the synthesis explicit.
- If this is an intro to a section, you might add one clause that signals what kinds of ‚Äúlimits‚Äù you will discuss (gender, labor exclusions) to forecast the argument.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Clarify terms and context:
  - If space allows, identify which programs excluded domestic workers (e.g., initial Social Security provisions) without adding citations beyond those you already plan to include, to increase precision.
  - If CCC has been introduced earlier, you can keep ‚ÄúCCC‚Äù; otherwise, expand on first mention as suggested.
- Consider a slightly more explicit link from the examples to the thesis:
  - Example: ‚ÄúThese policies expanded federal presence while preserving existing social hierarchies, underscoring the contradictions of New Deal reform.‚Äù

Formatting Guidance (Chicago Notes-Bibliography)
- Footnote markers: Keep [1], [2] in your draft for now. When you finalize:
  - Convert to superscript numerals.
  - Place note numbers after punctuation (e.g., after the period or comma) and after any closing quotation marks.
- Footnote entries (in the notes section at the bottom of the page):
  - Use full notes for first citations; abbreviated notes thereafter.
  - Single-space footnotes with a blank line between notes; indent the first line of each note.
- Page formatting:
  - 1-inch margins, 12-point Times New Roman, double-spaced text, first-line paragraph indent.
  - Page numbers in the header, upper-right.
  - Include a separate title page (centered title, your name, course, instructor, date) if your teacher requires it.
- Quotation formatting:
  - Use double quotation marks for quotations; single quotation marks for quotes within quotes.
  - Block quotations (five or more lines or roughly 100+ words): indent, no quotation marks, footnote number placed after the final punctuation of the block.
- Acronyms:
  - Spell out on first mention with acronym in parentheses; use acronym thereafter.

text: Title: How I Stopped Procrastinating By Doing Less

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your draft and goals. I‚Äôll focus on tightening structure, improving headings, fixing grammar, and making the post more scannable for web readers, while keeping your anecdotes and any links intact.

Quick questions to tailor the edit:
- Do you want to keep it to two tips, or are you open to adding a brief ‚ÄúTry this‚Äù checklist under each tip?
- Preferred length: keep it short (under ~350 words) or expand slightly with examples?
- Any links you plan to add (e.g., Twitter, a Not-To-Do template) I should account for in formatting?

Overview of the solution
- Line-by-line edits with reasoning to correct grammar, improve clarity, and standardize style.
- Structural suggestions for headings (H2/H3), bullets, and brief examples under each tip for scannability.
- Formatting guidance for web: short paragraphs, concise sentences, clear subheads, and bullet lists.

Line-by-line edits (with reasoning)
- Title: ‚ÄúTitle: How I Stopped Procrastinating By Doing Less‚Äù
  - Suggestion: Remove ‚ÄúTitle:‚Äù and use Title Case: ‚ÄúHow I Stopped Procrastinating by Doing Less‚Äù
  - Reason: Cleaner presentation; standard headline capitalization. Lowercase ‚Äúby‚Äù is correct in title case.

- Intro: ‚ÄúI used to think I need more apps to fix my procrastination. Turns out, I needed less‚Äîless options, less tabs, less guilt.‚Äù
  - Suggestion: ‚ÄúI used to think I needed more apps to fix my procrastination. Turns out, I needed less‚Äîfewer options, fewer tabs, and less guilt.‚Äù
  - Reason: Past tense consistency (‚Äúneeded‚Äù), correct count vs. mass noun usage (‚Äúfewer‚Äù for countable items like options/tabs; ‚Äúless‚Äù for mass nouns like guilt), add ‚Äúand‚Äù for smoother cadence.

- H2: ‚Äú## Tip 1: Make a Not-To-Do List‚Äù
  - Suggestion: Keep as is, or standardize hyphenation/capitalization: ‚Äú## Tip 1: Make a Not-To-Do List‚Äù
  - Reason: Consistent Title Case; ‚ÄúNot-To-Do List‚Äù is a widely recognized term.

- Body: ‚ÄúThis is not negative! It focuses your attention on what you should ignore.‚Äù
  - Suggestion: ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt negative‚Äîit helps you focus on what to ignore.‚Äù
  - Reason: More natural phrasing, contraction fits friendly tone, em dash improves flow, trims repetition (‚Äúyou should‚Äù).

- Example: ‚ÄúFor example, checking Twitter every 10 minutes is a bad loop I had.‚Äù
  - Suggestion: ‚ÄúFor example, checking Twitter every 10 minutes was a habit I fell into.‚Äù
  - Reason: Past tense alignment (‚Äúwas‚Äù), ‚Äúhabit‚Äù is clearer than ‚Äúloop,‚Äù ‚Äúfell into‚Äù is idiomatic and concise.

- H2: ‚Äú## Tip 2: Set "good enough" deadlines‚Äù
  - Suggestion: ‚Äú## Tip 2: Set ‚ÄòGood-Enough‚Äô Deadlines‚Äù
  - Reason: Title Case for headings, hyphenate ‚ÄúGood-Enough‚Äù when used as a compound adjective, use consistent quotation style (single quotes in headings are optional but keep consistent; alternatively remove quotes entirely for cleaner web style: ‚ÄúSet Good-Enough Deadlines‚Äù).

- Body: ‚ÄúPerfectionism is a trap. If you schedule shorter blocks and accept B+ work at first, you will move faster.‚Äù
  - Suggestion: ‚ÄúPerfectionism is a trap. Schedule shorter time blocks and accept B+ work initially‚Äîyou‚Äôll move faster.‚Äù
  - Reason: Imperative form is more direct for web; ‚Äútime blocks‚Äù adds clarity; ‚Äúinitially‚Äù is smoother; em dash creates a tight conclusion.

- H2: ‚Äú## Conclusion‚Äù
  - Suggestion: Keep as is.

- Conclusion body: ‚ÄúDoing less is surprisingly brave. You will feel weird at first, but then free.‚Äù
  - Suggestion: ‚ÄúDoing less can be surprisingly brave. It may feel uncomfortable at first, but the payoff is freedom.‚Äù
  - Reason: ‚ÄúCan be‚Äù softens the claim, ‚Äúuncomfortable‚Äù is clearer than ‚Äúweird,‚Äù and ‚Äúpayoff is freedom‚Äù lands with a stronger, positive close.

Overall Feedback
- Strong core idea and friendly tone. The simple, actionable tips fit a productivity audience.
- Key improvements: fix tense consistency, ‚Äúless‚Äù vs. ‚Äúfewer,‚Äù and make headings uniform and scannable. Add micro-examples or bullets under each tip for quick takeaways.

Spelling Edits
- No outright spelling errors found.
- Consistency: ‚ÄúTwitter‚Äù is correctly capitalized. Consider consistent quotation style (single vs. double quotes). For web headings, you can drop quotes.

Grammar Edits
- Past tense in the intro: ‚Äúneed‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúneeded.‚Äù
- Count vs. mass nouns: ‚Äúless options/tabs‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúfewer options/fewer tabs‚Äù; ‚Äúless guilt‚Äù stays ‚Äúless.‚Äù
- Idiomatic phrasing: ‚Äúbad loop I had‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúhabit I fell into.‚Äù
- Parallel structure and concision: remove ‚ÄúIf‚Äù and use imperative in Tip 2 for a tighter message.

Structural Suggestions
- Use H2 for each tip and H3 for brief examples or mini-checklists.
- Add scannable bullets under each tip:
  - Tip 1 bullets:
    - Try this: Write 3 things to ignore today (e.g., ‚ÄúTwitter refresh,‚Äù ‚Äúemail tabs after 7 p.m.,‚Äù ‚Äúnew app trials‚Äù).
    - Why it works: Reduces decision fatigue and removes low-value distractions.
  - Tip 2 bullets:
    - Try this: Set a 25‚Äì30 minute block; define ‚ÄúB+‚Äù criteria (clear, complete, not perfect).
    - Why it works: Time-boxing + ‚Äúgood-enough‚Äù standard speeds momentum.
- Consider a short one-line hook before the intro to grab attention (optional): ‚ÄúThe fastest way I beat procrastination? I started doing less.‚Äù
- Keep paragraphs short (1‚Äì3 sentences) and avoid long clauses for readability.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Add one sentence to connect the two tips: ‚ÄúBoth strategies eliminate decision friction so you can start faster.‚Äù
- Optional CTA: Invite readers to try one change today and share results (e.g., comment or share).
- If you plan to add links (e.g., to a Not-To-Do template or a time-boxing guide), place them at the end of each tip with descriptive anchor text.

Formatting Guidance (web style: H2/H3, short paragraphs, bullets)
- Headings:
  - H2: Tip titles (Title Case, avoid quotes when possible).
  - H3: Example or ‚ÄúTry this‚Äù under each tip.
- Paragraphs: 1‚Äì3 sentences each; aim for ~15‚Äì20 words per sentence.
- Bullets: Use simple, parallel phrasing; start with verbs (‚ÄúWrite,‚Äù ‚ÄúSet,‚Äù ‚ÄúDefine‚Äù).
- Links: Use descriptive anchors (‚ÄúNot-To-Do template‚Äù), keep them intact, and place them after the relevant sentence or as a bullet.
- Punctuation: Use em dashes sparingly for emphasis; avoid exclamation points unless intentional for tone.
- Consistency: Use Title Case for headings; sentence case in body copy.

Would you like me to generate a clean, edited version with H2/H3 headings, short paragraphs, and bullets, incorporating all these changes? I can also add an optional checklist under each tip and placeholder spots for any links you plan to include."

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your abstract and goals. I will focus on tense consistency, clarity, concision, and objective tone, while keeping all data values and claims unchanged and defining acronyms. Before I revise, a quick check: would you like me to keep the abstract strictly as a single paragraph (typical for scientific abstracts), or are short labeled sections acceptable for your science fair?

Overview of editorial guidance
- Shift methods and results to past tense for consistency.
- Remove first-person phrasing to maintain an objective tone.
- Define acronyms and units on first use (DIY, Œºm).
- Replace symbols (e.g., ‚Äú>‚Äù) with words for clarity.
- Split compound sentences to reduce ambiguity and improve concision.
- Keep claims intact while making limitations and implications clear.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
1) Original: ‚ÄúPlastic waste in waterways is increasing, which is why we designed a low-cost microplastic filter using natural fibers and tested it on local creek samples.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúPlastic waste in waterways is increasing. A low-cost microplastic filter using natural fibers was designed and tested on local creek samples.‚Äù
   Why: Removes first person to maintain objectivity; converts the causal clause into two clear sentences; uses past tense for methods; improves concision.

2) Original: ‚ÄúWe test filtration rates and particle counts with a DIY microscope rig.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúFiltration rates and particle counts were measured using a do-it-yourself (DIY) microscope rig.‚Äù
   Why: Past tense for methods; ‚Äúmeasured‚Äù is more precise than ‚Äútest‚Äù; defines the acronym DIY.

3) Original: ‚ÄúResults shows a 42% mean reduction in particles >100 Œºm after 30 minutes, and 18% reduction in 50‚Äì100 Œºm.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúResults showed a 42% mean reduction in particles greater than 100 micrometers (Œºm) after 30 minutes, and an 18% reduction in 50‚Äì100 Œºm particles.‚Äù
   Why: Corrects subject‚Äìverb agreement (‚ÄúResults showed‚Äù); maintains past tense; replaces ‚Äú>‚Äù with ‚Äúgreater than‚Äù for clarity; defines Œºm; adds ‚Äúparticles‚Äù for parallel phrasing.

4) Original: ‚ÄúThe limitations include inconsistent flow and clogging, but the design can be scaled for classroom use.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúLimitations include inconsistent flow and clogging. The design can be scaled for classroom use.‚Äù
   Why: Splits into two sentences for clarity and concision; retains claims without adding new ones; keeps objective tone.

Overall feedback
- The abstract‚Äôs content is strong and concise. The main improvement is tense consistency and removing first-person phrasing to meet common scientific abstract conventions.
- Defining acronyms and units increases clarity for judges who may not share the same technical background.

Spelling edits
- No spelling errors detected. Minor consistency note: use ‚Äúmicrometers‚Äù on first mention, then ‚ÄúŒºm.‚Äù

Grammar edits
- Change ‚ÄúWe test‚Äù to ‚Äúwere measured‚Äù (past tense for methods).
- Change ‚ÄúResults shows‚Äù to ‚ÄúResults showed‚Äù (subject‚Äìverb agreement and past tense).
- Use parallel structure in the results sentence by repeating ‚Äúparticles.‚Äù

Structural suggestions (Background, Methods, Results, Conclusion)
- Background: Keep the first sentence stating the problem. Consider one brief clause clarifying ‚Äúmicroplastics‚Äù if needed (e.g., ‚Äúmicroplastics‚Äîsmall plastic particles‚Äî‚Äù); optional.
- Methods: One sentence stating the filter materials (natural fibers), sample source (local creek), and measurement approach (DIY microscope rig).
- Results: One sentence with the two quantitative outcomes, units, and time frame.
- Conclusion: One sentence noting limitations and the potential for classroom scaling. If space allows, a neutral implication about future optimization (e.g., ‚ÄúFurther work will address flow consistency and clogging‚Äù) can be added without altering claims.

Opportunities for improvement
- If available, add the number of trials or samples to bolster rigor.
- Clarify what ‚Äúfiltration rates‚Äù refers to (e.g., flow rate or throughput) if judges may ask.
- Specify the type of natural fibers (e.g., cotton, jute) if that detail is permissible and available.

Formatting guidance
- Keep the abstract as a single paragraph under 250 words.
- Define acronyms/units at first use: do-it-yourself (DIY), micrometers (Œºm).
- Avoid symbols like ‚Äú>‚Äù; use words (‚Äúgreater than‚Äù).
- Maintain an objective tone and past tense for methods/results.

Would you like me to incorporate these edits into a polished version now?

Edited abstract (250-word limit, no first person, acronyms defined)
Plastic waste in waterways is increasing. A low-cost microplastic filter using natural fibers was designed and tested on local creek samples. Filtration rates and particle counts were measured using a do-it-yourself (DIY) microscope rig. Results showed a 42% mean reduction in particles greater than 100 micrometers (Œºm) after 30 minutes and an 18% reduction in 50‚Äì100 Œºm particles. Limitations include inconsistent flow and clogging. The design can be scaled for classroom use.

If you want, I can adjust this further (e.g., add sample size, specify fiber type, or merge sentences) while keeping the word count and claims intact."

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing this excerpt and your goals. Before I dive in, do you want me to edit just this paragraph or the full essay (current ~520 words)? If you have the full draft or the scholarship prompt, please paste or upload it so I can tailor suggestions and help you trim to 500 words while keeping your anecdotes and tone.

Overview of what I‚Äôll do
- Provide line-by-line edits with reasoning to polish tone and clarity, remove filler, and keep authenticity.
- Give targeted spelling and grammar notes.
- Suggest structure for a 500-word scholarship essay aimed at a committee.
- Highlight opportunities to strengthen coherence and impact.
- Offer formatting guidance for paragraphs of 4‚Äì6 sentences and the 500-word cap.
- Provide a clean revised paragraph you can drop in.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
- Original: ‚ÄúPeople tell me I ‚Äòdo too much,‚Äô but for me, busy is how I stayed steady when things were uncertain at home.‚Äù
  Suggested: ‚ÄúPeople tell me I ‚Äòdo too much,‚Äô but staying busy helped me stay steady when things at home were uncertain.‚Äù
  Reason: Tightens phrasing (‚Äústaying busy‚Äù vs. ‚Äúbusy is‚Äù), improves clarity, and maintains your authentic voice.

- Original: ‚ÄúBetween school, work, and caring for my little brother, I learned to prioritize hard choices.‚Äù
  Suggested: ‚ÄúBetween school, work, and caring for my little brother, I learned to prioritize when faced with hard choices.‚Äù
  Reason: ‚ÄúPrioritize hard choices‚Äù can sound like choosing difficulty; rephrasing clarifies that you prioritized tasks in the face of difficult decisions.

- Original: ‚ÄúOnce, I missed a shift to take him to an appointment and got written up, but I would do it again.‚Äù
  Suggested: ‚ÄúI once missed a shift to take him to an appointment and was written up‚Äîand I would do it again.‚Äù
  Reason: More formal (‚Äúwas written up‚Äù vs. ‚Äúgot written up‚Äù), smoother flow, and emphasis using an em dash.

- Original: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not perfect and I still overcommit, but I‚Äôve learned to ask for help and to say no.‚Äù
  Suggested: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not perfect‚ÄîI still overcommit‚Äîbut I‚Äôve learned to ask for help and to say no.‚Äù
  Reason: Punctuation clarifies contrast and reduces redundancy.

- Original: ‚ÄúThis scholarship would let me choose time for classes without risking our rent.‚Äù
  Suggested: ‚ÄúThis scholarship would let me focus on the classes I need without risking our rent.‚Äù
  Reason: ‚ÄúChoose time for classes‚Äù is ambiguous; ‚Äúfocus on the classes I need‚Äù is clearer and more purposeful.

Overall Feedback
- Your tone is sincere and hopeful, and the anecdote about your brother grounds your story in real responsibility.
- Clarity improves with small phrasing changes; tightening removes mild filler without losing authenticity.
- Consider connecting this personal resilience to your academic/career goals to show impact beyond the anecdote.

Spelling Edits
- No spelling errors detected in this excerpt.

Grammar Edits
- Replace ‚Äúgot written up‚Äù with ‚Äúwas written up‚Äù to maintain a professional tone for a scholarship essay.
- Use clearer parallel structures (‚Äústaying busy helped me stay steady‚Äù) to avoid awkward constructions.
- Adjust punctuation to emphasize contrasts (‚ÄúI‚Äôm not perfect‚ÄîI still overcommit‚Äîbut‚Ä¶‚Äù).

Structural Suggestions (for the full essay, 500 words)
- Paragraph 1 (Hook + context): Open with the ‚Äúdo too much‚Äù line and briefly frame the home situation and responsibilities.
- Paragraph 2 (Challenge + action): Describe the appointment/shift anecdote and another brief example of prioritizing under pressure.
- Paragraph 3 (Growth + skills): Explain how you learned to ask for help and set boundaries; name 2‚Äì3 skills (time management, resilience, communication).
- Paragraph 4 (Academic/career path): Link those skills to your major, classes, and long-term goals; show how the scholarship unlocks specific steps (e.g., a lab, certification, required course sequence).
- Paragraph 5 (Impact + fit): Close with how the scholarship reduces financial strain (rent) and enables you to contribute to campus/community; end with a forward-looking, sincere statement.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Add one specific detail to show academic direction (major or a key class you need) and one community impact you aim to make; this strengthens committee confidence.

Formatting Guidance
- Keep 4‚Äì6 sentences per paragraph; aim for 5 paragraphs total to naturally fit ~450‚Äì500 words.
- Trim by favoring concrete verbs over phrases (e.g., ‚Äúfocus on‚Äù vs. ‚Äúchoose time for‚Äù), and combine sentences with clear punctuation to reduce filler.
- Avoid new quotes or epigraphs to respect your constraint; use straightforward transitions (‚ÄúBecause,‚Äù ‚ÄúAs a result,‚Äù ‚ÄúSo‚Äù).

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your goals and the link. I‚Äôm ready to provide line-by-line edits with reasoning, plus overall feedback, structural suggestions, and MLA formatting guidance tailored to an 11th-grade English audience.

Access to your document

Before I review, a few quick questions to tailor feedback:
- Do you have a teacher-provided rubric or specific criteria (e.g., minimum sources, required number of quotes, argument vs. informative)?

Overview of how I‚Äôll help (once I have the text)

- Line-by-line edits with reasoning:

- Structural suggestions: Organization of introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion; paragraph unity; logical flow; topic sentences; evidence-to-analysis ratio.

- Opportunities for improvement: Areas to strengthen argumentation, evidence, analysis depth, and cohesion.

Sometimes I say things like ‚ÄúI have 15 years‚Äù because that‚Äôs how we say it in Spanish, and people laugh a little.     "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your paragraph and goals. Quick question before I finalize the rewrite: would you like to keep any Spanish words as cultural markers (for example, italicized with an English translation in parentheses), or should we fully standardize everything into American English in the final version?

Overview of what I‚Äôll do
- Standardize the dialect to American English while keeping your meaning and cultural references.
- Fix grammar and tense issues (e.g., subject-verb agreement, idiomatic expressions).
- Provide line-by-line edits with reasoning.
- Suggest small structural changes for clarity and flow.
- Offer formatting guidance appropriate for a personal narrative paragraph for a high school teacher.

Overall Feedback
- Your paragraph clearly conveys the experience of code-switching and the emotions around it. The main edits are minor: replacing nonstandard phrasing (‚ÄúIt be‚Äù) with standard American English, clarifying idioms (‚ÄúI have 15 years‚Äù), and tightening wording for clarity (‚Äúspeaking both‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúspeaking both languages‚Äù).
- The flow is already strong; a small tweak to sentence structure will make it even clearer and more polished for a classroom audience.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
1) Original: ‚ÄúMi familia and I moved to the U.S. when I was 10, and I used to translate for my parents at la escuela office.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúMy family and I moved to the U.S. when I was ten, and I used to translate for my parents at the school office.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - Standardize to American English: ‚ÄúMi familia‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúMy family‚Äù; ‚Äúla escuela office‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúthe school office.‚Äù
   - Style: Spell out small numbers in narrative prose (‚Äúten‚Äù instead of ‚Äú10‚Äù) for a more formal, polished feel.
   - Clarity: ‚Äúthe school office‚Äù is the natural phrasing in American English.

2) Original: ‚ÄúSometimes I say things like ‚ÄòI have 15 years‚Äô because that‚Äôs how we say it in Spanish, and people laugh a little.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúSometimes I say things like ‚ÄòI have fifteen years‚Äô because that‚Äôs how we say it in Spanish, and people laugh a little.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - Preserve the cultural reference by keeping the quoted phrase as an example of direct translation.
   - Style: Spell out ‚Äúfifteen‚Äù in the quote to match the rest of the paragraph‚Äôs number style.
   - This sentence can remain as one, but you could split it for emphasis (see Structural Suggestions).

3) Original: ‚ÄúIt be confusing switching back and forth, but I‚Äôm learning to slow down and think in English first when needed, and also not be ashamed of speaking both.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúIt can be confusing to switch between languages, but I‚Äôm learning to slow down, think in English first when needed, and not be ashamed of speaking both languages.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - Grammar: Replace nonstandard ‚ÄúIt be‚Äù with standard ‚ÄúIt can be.‚Äù
   - Clarity: ‚Äúswitch between languages‚Äù specifies what you‚Äôre switching.
   - Parallel structure: ‚Äúslow down, think‚Ä¶, and not be ashamed‚Ä¶‚Äù reads more smoothly.
   - Specificity: ‚Äúboth languages‚Äù clarifies ‚Äúboth.‚Äù

Spelling Edits
- ‚ÄúMi familia‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúMy family‚Äù (standard American English).
- ‚Äúla escuela office‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúthe school office‚Äù (standard American English).
- ‚Äú10‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúten‚Äù and ‚Äú15‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúfifteen‚Äù (style consistency in narrative prose).

Grammar Edits
- ‚ÄúIt be confusing‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúIt can be confusing‚Äù (subject-verb agreement and standard usage).
- Add ‚Äúlanguages‚Äù after ‚Äúspeaking both‚Äù for clarity and completeness.
- Adjusted parallel structure in the final sentence for smoother reading.

Structural Suggestions
- Consider splitting the second sentence into two for emphasis:
  - ‚ÄúSometimes I say things like ‚ÄòI have fifteen years‚Äô because that‚Äôs how we say it in Spanish. People laugh a little.‚Äù
- Alternatively, begin with a general statement about switching languages, then give the example:
  - ‚ÄúSwitching between languages can be confusing. Sometimes I say things like ‚ÄòI have fifteen years‚Äô because that‚Äôs how we say it in Spanish, and people laugh a little.‚Äù
- Both options slightly increase clarity and rhetorical impact while keeping your original meaning.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Add a brief detail about what you translated at the school office (forms, conversations with staff) to give a concrete image.
- Include one sentence about how the laughter made you feel and what changed as you learned to navigate both languages; this deepens the personal reflection.
- If appropriate for your teacher, you could name ‚Äúcode-switching‚Äù explicitly once, to show awareness of the concept.

Formatting Guidance
- Use standard American English throughout; if you keep any Spanish terms, consider italicizing them and/or adding a brief parenthetical translation the first time they appear (e.g., escuela [school]).
- Spell out numbers from zero to nine in narrative prose; for ages and simple counts, spelling out ‚Äúten‚Äù and ‚Äúfifteen‚Äù is acceptable and reads more formal.
- Use straight quotation marks consistently for typed work unless your teacher prefers curly quotes.

Would you like me to fully standardize (remove Spanish words) or keep one or two Spanish terms italicized as cultural markers? I can tailor the final paragraph either way.

Edited paragraph (standard American English)
My family and I moved to the U.S. when I was ten, and I used to translate for my parents at the school office. Sometimes I say things like ‚ÄúI have fifteen years‚Äù because that‚Äôs how we say it in Spanish, and people laugh a little. It can be confusing to switch between languages, but I‚Äôm learning to slow down, think in English first when needed, and not be ashamed of speaking both languages.

If you‚Äôd like, I can generate a version that includes one italicized Spanish term with a brief parenthetical translation, or expand the paragraph with an additional sentence for reflection."

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your goals and the draft. To tailor the edit, one quick question: do you prefer the executive summary in a tight paragraph or in labeled bullets (Problem/Solution/Results/Plan/Risks)? Also, do you have a target word count?

H2: Overview of Editorial Approach
- Focus: Make the summary crisp, correct grammar and tone, and strengthen structure for small business owners.
- Method: Line-by-line edits with reasoning, then structural and formatting guidance using H2/H3 headings, bullets, and bold key terms.
- Constraints respected: All figures retained; no new claims; confident, clear, non-hype tone.

H2: Overall Feedback
- The core message is clear, but sentences can be tightened and reordered for logical flow: Problem ‚Üí Solution ‚Üí Results ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Risks.
- Grammar adjustments (subject‚Äìverb agreement, article use, punctuation) will improve clarity and professionalism.
- Avoid contractions for a formal executive summary, and use precise, parallel phrasing.

H2: Line-by-Line Edits with Reasoning
- Original: ‚ÄúOur platform helps local shops get discovered by nearby customers using geo-targeted notifications and simple onboarding.‚Äù
  - Edited: ‚ÄúOur platform helps local shops get discovered by nearby customers through geo‚Äëtargeted notifications and a simple onboarding process.‚Äù
  - Reasoning: ‚ÄúThrough‚Äù clarifies the mechanism; ‚Äúa simple onboarding process‚Äù adds the missing article and uses parallel noun phrasing.

- Original: ‚ÄúThe problem is small shops don‚Äôt have time or money to run ads that works.‚Äù
  - Edited: ‚ÄúThe problem: small shops do not have the time or budget to run ads that work.‚Äù
  - Reasoning: Remove filler (‚ÄúThe problem is‚Äù), avoid contraction (‚Äúdo not‚Äù), add articles (‚Äúthe‚Äù), use ‚Äúbudget‚Äù for business tone, and fix subject‚Äìverb agreement (‚Äúads that work‚Äù).

- Original: ‚ÄúWith our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased 12% in 6 weeks, with 9 stores renewing for the next quarter.‚Äù
  - Edited: ‚ÄúIn a pilot with 18 stores, average foot traffic increased 12% over six weeks; nine stores renewed for the next quarter.‚Äù
  - Reasoning: ‚ÄúIn a pilot with‚Ä¶‚Äù reads cleaner; ‚Äúover six weeks‚Äù is idiomatic; semicolon connects closely related results; spell out numbers under 10 for consistency.

- Original: ‚ÄúWe plan to scale to 100 stores by Q3 with a break-even at 320 paying locations.‚Äù
  - Edited: ‚ÄúWe plan to scale to 100 stores by Q3; we break even at 320 paying locations.‚Äù
  - Reasoning: Split the sentence for clarity; use present tense for a standing financial threshold; hyphen unnecessary when ‚Äúbreak even‚Äù functions as a verb.

- Original: ‚ÄúRisks include churn and notification fatigue which we plan to mitigate with controls.‚Äù
  - Edited: ‚ÄúRisks include churn and notification fatigue, which we plan to mitigate with controls.‚Äù
  - Reasoning: Add the comma before the nonrestrictive clause; keep ‚Äúcontrols‚Äù as stated without adding new claims.

H2: Spelling Edits
- ‚Äúgeo-targeted‚Äù ‚Üí keep hyphenated as ‚Äúgeo‚Äëtargeted‚Äù for consistency with compound modifiers.
- ‚Äúonboarding‚Äù ‚Üí correct as one word.
- Numbers: Spell out ‚Äúsix‚Äù and ‚Äúnine‚Äù for readability; keep larger figures numeric (12%, 18, 100, 320, Q3).

H2: Grammar Edits
- Subject‚Äìverb agreement: ‚Äúads that works‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúads that work.‚Äù
- Article usage: Add ‚Äúa‚Äù before ‚Äúsimple onboarding process‚Äù; add ‚Äúthe‚Äù before ‚Äútime or budget.‚Äù
- Tense consistency:
  - Present: platform capability and break-even threshold.
  - Past: pilot results.
  - Future: scaling plan.
- Punctuation: Use a semicolon to link closely related independent clauses; add comma for nonrestrictive clause (‚Äúfatigue, which‚Ä¶‚Äù).

H2: Structural Suggestions
- Use a Problem ‚Üí Solution ‚Üí Results ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Risks order for immediate comprehension.
- Separate metrics into the Results section to highlight impact.
- Keep sentences short (10‚Äì18 words) and parallel for scannability.
- Consider labeled bullets if your audience prefers quick scanning.

H2: Opportunities for Improvement
- Clarify ‚Äúcontrols‚Äù briefly if allowed (e.g., frequency or relevance controls). If not, keep as is to avoid new claims.
- If you have a specific pricing or definition of ‚Äúpaying locations,‚Äù you can include it in a later section, not the executive summary.

H2: Formatting Guidance
- H2: Executive Summary
  - H3: Problem
    - Small shops do not have the time or budget to run ads that work.
  - H3: Solution
    - Our platform helps local shops get discovered by nearby customers through geo‚Äëtargeted notifications and a simple onboarding process.
  - H3: Results
    - In a pilot with 18 stores, average foot traffic increased 12% over six weeks; nine stores renewed for the next quarter.
  - H3: Plan
    - Scale to 100 stores by Q3; break even at 320 paying locations.
  - H3: Risks
    - Risks include churn and notification fatigue, which we plan to mitigate with controls.
- Use bold for key metrics and terms (e.g., ‚Äú12%,‚Äù ‚ÄúQ3,‚Äù ‚Äú320 paying locations,‚Äù ‚Äúgeo‚Äëtargeted notifications‚Äù).

H2: Proposed Edited Executive Summary (Bullet Format)
- H3: Problem
  - Small shops do not have the time or budget to run ads that work.
- H3: Solution
  - Our platform helps local shops get discovered by nearby customers through geo‚Äëtargeted notifications and a simple onboarding process.
- H3: Results

- H3: Plan
  - Scale to 100 stores by Q3; break even at 320 paying locations.
- H3: Risks
  - Risks include churn and notification fatigue, which we plan to mitigate with controls.

Would you like me to deliver this as a single paragraph version, or keep the labeled bullets? If you share your preferred length, I can generate the final edited text now."

    "testinput": "goals: Turn this outline into a coherent, well-structured speech; fix grammar and transitions

text: - Hook: ‚ÄúImagine if your phone is the boss of you.‚Äù
- Problem: Screen time going up; attention going down.
- Evidence: grades slipping, sleep shorter, I felt it last semester.
- Counter: Phones are tools‚Äîyes, but tools shape us.
- Solution: 3 steps: grayscale, no-phone mornings, buddy check-ins.
- Close: ‚ÄúYou deserve your attention back.‚Äù Ask audience to try it for 7 days.",
    "scenario": "",
    "generation": 0,
    "testuid": "baseline-test-0dabpice3",
    "baseline": true,
    "inverse": false,
    "groundtruthScore": 65,
    "groundtruthModel": "gpt-5-2025-08-07",
    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your outline and goals. I can turn this into a coherent, motivational speech with smooth transitions, and provide line-by-line edits, structural suggestions, and speaking-note formatting. Before I finalize, two quick questions:
- Is a brief personal anecdote okay to include (you mention ‚ÄúI felt it last semester‚Äù)?
- Does your assignment require at least one cited statistic, or is a general reference to research acceptable?

Overview of approach
- Tighten each line for grammar, clarity, and parallel structure.
- Add transitions that connect each section and build momentum.
- Expand the solution into clear, actionable steps that fit a 5‚Äì6 minute delivery.
- Format the speaking outline with cue words and timing estimates so it‚Äôs easy to deliver.

Overall Feedback
- Strengths: Clear problem-solution frame, relatable hook, concise plan with three practical steps, strong close and call to action.
- Main improvements: Use subjunctive grammar in the hook, add a specific example in the evidence section, strengthen the counterargument, and smooth transitions between sections. Keep each step behaviorally specific so your audience can try it for 7 days.

Spelling Edits (with reasoning)
- grayscale ‚Üí correct as one word. Reason: Standard usage for display setting.
- no-phone mornings ‚Üí keep hyphenated. Reason: Hyphen clarifies the compound adjective.
- check-ins ‚Üí include hyphen. Reason: ‚ÄúCheck-in‚Äù is hyphenated in noun form; plural is ‚Äúcheck-ins.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúScreen time going up; attention going down.‚Äù ‚Üí Keep ‚Äúscreen time‚Äù as two words; ‚Äúattention‚Äù is correct.

Grammar Edits (with reasoning)
- Hook: ‚ÄúImagine if your phone is the boss of you.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúImagine if your phone were the boss of you.‚Äù Reason: Use the subjunctive ‚Äúwere‚Äù for a hypothetical.
- Evidence: ‚Äúgrades slipping, sleep shorter, I felt it last semester.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúGrades slipped, my sleep got shorter, and I felt it last semester.‚Äù Reason: Parallel verb forms and add a conjunction to avoid a comma splice.
- Counter: ‚ÄúPhones are tools‚Äîyes, but tools shape us.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúPhones are tools‚Äîyes. But tools also shape us.‚Äù Reason: Split into two sentences for emphasis; ‚Äúalso‚Äù signals concession with contrast.
- Solution: ‚Äú3 steps: grayscale, no-phone mornings, buddy check-ins.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúThree steps: turn on grayscale, try no-phone mornings, and set up buddy check-ins.‚Äù Reason: Spell out ‚Äúthree‚Äù in speech and use parallel imperative phrases.
- Close: ‚ÄúAsk audience to try it for 7 days.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúAsk the audience to try it for seven days.‚Äù Reason: Spell out single-digit numbers in speech.

Structural Suggestions (with reasoning)
- Order: Hook ‚Üí Problem ‚Üí Evidence (personal and one brief stat) ‚Üí Counterargument ‚Üí Solution (three steps) ‚Üí Call to Action ‚Üí Close. Reason: This sequence builds logic and motivation, keeping the audience engaged.
- Add transitions: Use ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what that looks like,‚Äù ‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs a catch,‚Äù and ‚ÄúSo what can we do?‚Äù to guide listeners.
- Make each step concrete: Add ‚Äúhow,‚Äù ‚Äúwhen,‚Äù and ‚Äúwhy it helps‚Äù for each step to increase follow-through and fit the 7-day challenge.
- Time cues: Aim for roughly 30‚Äì45 seconds per early section, 2 minutes for the solution, and 1 minute for the call to action and close, totaling about 5‚Äì6 minutes.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Include one credible data point on attention, grades, or sleep (e.g., a brief stat from the CDC, APA, or a school survey). Keep it short: one sentence.
- Add a one-sentence personal anecdote to humanize the problem.
- Offer a simple way to measure progress (e.g., ‚ÄúNotice how many times you pick up your phone before lunch,‚Äù or ‚ÄúTrack sleep for seven days‚Äù).
- Preempt objections: Acknowledge phones help us study and connect; you‚Äôre offering small guardrails, not a ban.

Formatting Guidance for Speaking Notes
- Use clear section headers in ALL CAPS: HOOK, PROBLEM, EVIDENCE, COUNTER, SOLUTION, CALL TO ACTION, CLOSE.
- Keep one idea per line; aim for short phrases, not full paragraphs.
- Add cue words in brackets: [PAUSE], [LOOK UP], [SLOW DOWN], [SHOW OF HANDS].
- Put transitions on their own lines to help delivery.
- Include approximate time per section, so you hit 5‚Äì6 minutes.
- Bold is optional; if not available, use caps for emphasis; underline key phrases by writing them in caps (e.g., YOU DESERVE YOUR ATTENTION BACK).

Edited Speaking Outline (5‚Äì6 minutes, with cue words)
HOOK (0:30)
- Imagine if your phone were the boss of you. [PAUSE] What would it tell you to do‚Äînow, now, now? [LOOK UP]
  Reason: Subjunctive ‚Äúwere‚Äù for hypothetical; short punchy questions create engagement.

PROBLEM (0:45)
- Our screen time is going up; our attention is going down. [PAUSE]
- The cost? More distraction, less deep focus, and decisions that feel rushed.
  Reason: Parallel structure (‚Äúgoing up / going down‚Äù); names concrete consequences.

EVIDENCE (1:00)
- Quick stat: Research links heavy screen use with shorter sleep and lower academic performance. [PAUSE]
- My example: Last semester, my grades slipped and my sleep got shorter because I kept scrolling past midnight. [SLOW DOWN]
  Reason: One concise research claim, plus a personal anecdote to ground the message.

COUNTERARGUMENT (0:45)
- Phones are tools‚Äîyes. But tools also shape us. [PAUSE]
- I‚Äôm not saying ditch your phone; I‚Äôm saying add small guardrails so the tool serves you. [LOOK UP]
  Reason: Acknowledge benefits; reframe as balance, not abstinence.

TRANSITION (0:10)
- So what can we do‚Äîstarting this week? [PAUSE]
  Reason: Signals the move to solutions and the 7-day challenge.

SOLUTION: THREE STEPS (2:00)
- Step 1: Turn on grayscale. [PAUSE]
  - How: Switch your display to grayscale after 8 p.m. on weekdays. [PAUSE]
  - Why: Less color = fewer ‚Äúclick me‚Äù cues; it makes late-night scrolling less tempting.
  Reason: Imperative framing; time-bound instruction increases follow-through.

- Step 2: No-phone mornings. [PAUSE]
  - How: For the first 30 minutes after you wake up, no social apps or texts. Start with water, stretch, and your first task. [LOOK UP]
  - Why: Protects your freshest attention; sets your focus before notifications set it for you.
  Reason: Concrete duration and replacement behaviors reduce friction.

- Step 3: Buddy check-ins. [PAUSE]
  - How: Pair with a classmate today; send a one-line check-in each morning for seven days (‚ÄúGrayscale on, 30-min no-phone done‚Äù). [SMILE]
  - Why: Accountability beats willpower. Share wins; reset if you slip.
  Reason: Simple script lowers barrier; normalizes imperfection.

CALL TO ACTION (0:45)
- Try these three steps for seven days. Start tonight: grayscale at 8 p.m. [PAUSE]
- Tomorrow morning: 30 minutes no phone. [PAUSE]
- Before you leave class: pick a buddy. [SHOW OF HANDS] Who‚Äôs in?
  Reason: Break CTA into immediate, next, and today actions; invite participation.

CLOSE (0:30)
- You deserve your attention back. [PAUSE] Give it seven days‚Äîand see what changes.
- If it helps, keep it. If not, adjust. But let your phone serve you, not boss you. [LOOK UP]
  Reason: Motivational yet grounded; emphasizes autonomy and experiment.

Line-by-line Edits with Reasoning (comparing your original lines)
- Hook: ‚ÄúImagine if your phone is the boss of you.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúImagine if your phone were the boss of you.‚Äù
  Reason: The subjunctive ‚Äúwere‚Äù fits hypothetical statements; it also sounds more polished in speech.

- Problem: ‚ÄúScreen time going up; attention going down.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúOur screen time is going up; our attention is going down.‚Äù
  Reason: Add ‚Äúour‚Äù for audience inclusion; keep parallel structure for rhythm.

- Evidence: ‚Äúgrades slipping, sleep shorter, I felt it last semester.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúMy grades slipped, my sleep got shorter, and I felt it last semester.‚Äù
  Reason: Use parallel past-tense verbs; add ‚Äúmy‚Äù for clarity and personal ownership; include ‚Äúand‚Äù to avoid a comma splice.

- Counter: ‚ÄúPhones are tools‚Äîyes, but tools shape us.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúPhones are tools‚Äîyes. But tools also shape us.‚Äù
  Reason: Split for emphasis; ‚Äúalso‚Äù signals concession then contrast, improving flow.

- Solution: ‚Äú3 steps: grayscale, no-phone mornings, buddy check-ins.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúThree steps: turn on grayscale, try no-phone mornings, and set up buddy check-ins.‚Äù
  Reason: Spell out numbers in speech; use parallel imperative phrases to make the plan actionable.

- Close: ‚ÄúYou deserve your attention back.‚Äù Ask audience to try it for 7 days. ‚Üí ‚ÄúYou deserve your attention back. Try it for seven days.‚Äù
  Reason: Keep the impactful sentence; make the call to action direct; spell out ‚Äúseven.‚Äù

Would you like me to generate a full speech script based on this outline (about 900‚Äì1,000 words for 5‚Äì6 minutes)? I can also tailor the evidence section with a specific statistic if you share whether a citation is required."

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your narrative and goals. Before I dive in, quick check: Do you have a preferred tense for the narrative (e.g., mostly past tense with present reflections at the end), and is there any word count or teacher requirement I should keep in mind?

Overview of the guidance I‚Äôll provide
- I‚Äôll make line-by-line edits to fix tense consistency, clarify chronology, and improve sentence variety and flow while keeping all major events and avoiding fictional additions.
- I‚Äôll explain the reasoning for each change.
- I‚Äôll offer structural suggestions to strengthen the arc (injury ‚Üí therapy ‚Üí progress ‚Üí track lesson).
- I‚Äôll point out opportunities to enhance clarity and reflection without inventing details.
- I‚Äôll provide formatting tips for a standard essay paragraph.

Overall Feedback
- The core idea is strong: the injury becomes the catalyst for a hopeful commitment to track and a lesson in patience and progress.
- Your main challenge is tense inconsistency (mixing present and past) and a slightly unclear timeline.
- With consistent past tense in the narrative and a present/reflection sentence at the end, the piece will read more smoothly and feel more confident.
- A few small wording changes will clarify the chronology and improve sentence variety without changing your story.

Spelling Edits
- No spelling errors detected in the original text.

Grammar Edits (line-by-line with reasoning)
1) Original: ‚ÄúThe day I broke my ankle is the day I decided to join track, which doesn‚Äôt make sense until I explain.‚Äù
   Suggested edit: ‚ÄúThe day I broke my ankle was the day I decided to join track‚Äîa choice that makes more sense once I explain.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - Switch ‚Äúis‚Äù to ‚Äúwas‚Äù to match past-tense narration.
   - ‚ÄúA choice that makes more sense once I explain‚Äù is slightly tighter and avoids the vague ‚Äúwhich.‚Äù
   - The em dash adds variety and emphasis.

2) Original: ‚ÄúI am limping down the stairs last winter when the ice was invisible, and then I fell.‚Äù
   Suggested edit: ‚ÄúLast winter, I was limping down the stairs when I hit invisible ice, and I fell.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - Change ‚ÄúI am limping‚Äù to ‚ÄúI was limping‚Äù to keep past tense with ‚Äúlast winter.‚Äù
   - ‚ÄúHit invisible ice‚Äù is a clear, concise phrase that explains the slip without adding new fictional detail.
   - Replace ‚Äúand then I fell‚Äù with ‚Äúand I fell‚Äù to streamline the action.

   Note: If ‚Äúlimping‚Äù here means you were already injured before this fall, consider clarifying. If you were just moving cautiously, ‚Äúwalking carefully‚Äù may be more precise. I didn‚Äôt change it because it might be true to your experience.

3) Original: ‚ÄúLater, in physical therapy, I learn patience I didn‚Äôt know I had.‚Äù
   Suggested edit: ‚ÄúLater, in physical therapy, I learned patience I didn‚Äôt know I had.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - ‚ÄúLearned‚Äù keeps the narrative in past tense.
   - The rest of the sentence reads well and supports the reflective tone.

4) Original: ‚ÄúBy spring I was jogging, then I am running.‚Äù
   Suggested edit: ‚ÄúBy spring, I was jogging; then I was running.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - Make both verbs past tense for consistency.
   - Use a semicolon to add sentence variety and show progression.
   - Keep ‚Äúthen‚Äù to maintain your original timeline without adding specifics.

5) Original: ‚ÄúJoining track taught me to measure progress in millimeters before it shows up as miles.‚Äù
   Suggested edit (Option A, fully past tense): ‚ÄúJoining track taught me to measure progress in millimeters before it showed up as miles.‚Äù
   Suggested edit (Option B, reflective present perfect): ‚ÄúJoining track has taught me to measure progress in millimeters before it shows up as miles.‚Äù
   Reasoning:
   - Option A keeps the entire piece in past tense.
   - Option B shifts to present reflection at the end, which can feel more hopeful and ongoing. Choose based on your preference and teacher guidelines.

Structural Suggestions
- Keep this as one cohesive paragraph for a portfolio, but ensure the chronology is crystal clear:
  1) Hook with the ankle-break/decision sentence.
  2) Describe the fall (winter ‚Üí stairs ‚Üí invisible ice ‚Üí fall).
  3) Move to physical therapy and the patience lesson.
  4) Mark progress (spring ‚Üí jogging ‚Üí running).
  5) Conclude with the broader takeaway about measuring progress (either in past tense or present perfect).
- Consider adding one brief transition phrase between therapy and spring to smooth the time jump, e.g., ‚ÄúAfter weeks of exercises,‚Äù only if it‚Äôs accurate to your experience. If not, the current ‚ÄúBy spring‚Ä¶‚Äù works.
- If you expand this for a longer essay, split into two paragraphs: (1) incident and decision; (2) recovery and lesson.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Clarify ‚Äúlimping‚Äù: If you were limping before the fall, a brief clarification would prevent confusion. If you weren‚Äôt, consider ‚Äúwalking carefully‚Äù or ‚Äúmoving slowly‚Äù (only if true).
- Add one reflective phrase to deepen the hopeful tone without inventing events, e.g., ‚Äústeady, patient steps‚Äù or ‚Äúsmall gains that mattered‚Äù‚Äîonly if these match your experience.
- Vary sentence openings to avoid repetition (start one sentence with a time phrase, another with a participial phrase, etc.). The edits above already introduce some of this variety.

Formatting Guidance
- For a standard essay paragraph in a portfolio:
  - Use Times New Roman or a similar serif font, 12-point, double-spaced, with 1-inch margins.
  - Indent the first line of the paragraph.
  - Keep consistent tense choice: either all past, or past with a final present-perfect reflection.
  - Include a strong concluding sentence that ties the learning to your growth as a student/athlete.

Would you like me to rewrite the paragraph with these edits applied? I can provide two versions (all past tense vs. ending in present perfect) so you can choose which fits your portfolio.

If helpful now, here are both edited versions:

Version A (all past tense):
‚ÄúThe day I broke my ankle was the day I decided to join track‚Äîa choice that makes more sense once I explain. Last winter, I was limping down the stairs when I hit invisible ice, and I fell. Later, in physical therapy, I learned patience I didn‚Äôt know I had. By spring, I was jogging; then I was running. Joining track taught me to measure progress in millimeters before it showed up as miles.‚Äù

Version B (ending in present reflection):
‚ÄúThe day I broke my ankle was the day I decided to join track‚Äîa choice that makes more sense once I explain. Last winter, I was limping down the stairs when I hit invisible ice, and I fell. Later, in physical therapy, I learned patience I didn‚Äôt know I had. By spring, I was jogging; then I was running. Joining track has taught me to measure progress in millimeters before it shows up as miles.‚Äù

Let me know which you prefer, and if you want me to tweak ‚Äúlimping‚Äù based on what‚Äôs accurate to your experience or adjust tone further toward reflective/hopeful."

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your email and goals. Quick check before I finalize: would you like me to include your course name/section (and possibly student ID) in the email signature? That can help professors quickly locate your submission policy and records.

Overview of the solution
- I will make the tone more professional and concise, standardize date and time formatting, and tighten the brief context.
- I‚Äôll improve specificity in the subject line and adjust greeting/closing for a respectful, polished request.
- I‚Äôll provide line-by-line edits with reasons, then give structural and formatting guidance.
- I‚Äôll also offer a clean, ready-to-send version.

Overall Feedback
- Your request is clear and appropriately brief. To make it more professional:
  - Use a formal greeting and closing.
  - Avoid contractions.
  - Standardize dates/times (spell out months; add periods in ‚Äúp.m.‚Äù).
  - Lead with the request, follow with one concise line of context, then state the new deadline.
  - Consider adding course info in the signature.

Spelling Edits
- ‚ÄúSept‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúSeptember‚Äù
  - Reason: Spell out months in professional correspondence for clarity.
- ‚Äú48 hour‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äú48-hour‚Äù
  - Reason: Hyphenate compound adjectives before nouns.
- ‚Äú11:59pm‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äú11:59 p.m.‚Äù
  - Reason: Standard time formatting: space before ‚Äúp.m.‚Äù and periods included.

Grammar Edits
- ‚Äúrequesting a 48 hour extension for the research brief‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúrequesting a 48‚Äëhour extension on the research brief‚Äù
  - Reason: ‚Äúon‚Äù is the more common preposition for extensions tied to assignments; hyphenation fixed.
- ‚ÄúI‚Äôve completed‚Äù / ‚ÄúI‚Äôm behind‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúI have completed‚Äù / ‚ÄúI need additional time‚Äù
  - Reason: Avoid contractions in formal tone; ‚Äúneed additional time‚Äù is concise and neutral.
- ‚Äúintegrating the sources and formatting the citations‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúto integrate sources and finalize citations‚Äù
  - Reason: Parallel structure and more concise wording.

Structural Suggestions
- Suggested flow:
  1) Clear request (what, for which assignment, due date).
  2) One-sentence neutral context (no excuses; what remains to complete).
  3) Specific new submission time (date and time).
  4) Appreciation.
  5) Optional: invite questions or include course info.
- Keep the email to 3‚Äì5 sentences and one short paragraph.
- Use a more specific subject line that includes the extension length and assignment.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Add course name/section in your signature to streamline the professor‚Äôs review.
- Mention time zone if there‚Äôs any ambiguity (e.g., ‚Äú11:59 p.m. ET‚Äù).
- Consider acknowledging syllabus policy if relevant (e.g., ‚Äúper the course policy‚Äù), but only if it‚Äôs concise and accurate.

Formatting Guidance
- Subject line options:
  - Request for 48‚ÄëHour Extension: Research Brief due September 28
  - 48‚ÄëHour Extension Request ‚Äî Research Brief due September 28
- Greeting: Use ‚ÄúDear Professor Ahmed,‚Äù for a professional tone.
- Closing: Use ‚ÄúThank you for your consideration.‚Äù followed by ‚ÄúBest regards,‚Äù or ‚ÄúSincerely,‚Äù.
- Signature block:
  - Riley [Last Name]
  - Course Name and Section (e.g., HIST 210, Section 02)
  - University Email | Optional Student ID
- Dates/times: Spell out months; use ‚Äú11:59 p.m.‚Äù with periods.
- Keep paragraphs single-spaced with a blank line between sections if longer than one paragraph (here, one paragraph is fine).

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
- Original: Subject: Extension for Research Brief Due Sept 28
  - Edit: Subject: Request for 48‚ÄëHour Extension: Research Brief due September 28
  - Reason: Adds the extension length for clarity, uses title case, and spells out the month.
- Original: Hi Professor Ahmed,
  - Edit: Dear Professor Ahmed,
  - Reason: More formal and appropriate for a college professor.
- Original: I am requesting a 48 hour extension for the research brief due Sept 28.
  - Edit: I am writing to request a 48‚Äëhour extension on the research brief due September 28.
  - Reason: ‚Äúon‚Äù is smoother; hyphenate ‚Äú48‚Äëhour‚Äù; spell out month; ‚ÄúI am writing to request‚Äù is a common formal opener.
- Original: I‚Äôve completed most of the reading but I‚Äôm behind on integrating the sources and formatting the citations.
  - Edit: I have completed most of the reading and need additional time to integrate sources and finalize citations.
  - Reason: Avoid contractions; neutral phrasing; parallel structure; concise wording.
- Original: If approved, I will submit by Sept 30 at 11:59pm.
  - Edit: If approved, I will submit by September 30 at 11:59 p.m.
  - Reason: Standardize date/time formatting; retain the exact deadline.
- Original: Thank you for considering it.
  - Edit: Thank you for your consideration.
  - Reason: More conventional phrasing for formal emails.
- Original: Best,
  - Edit: Best regards,
  - Reason: Slightly more formal closing without being wordy.
- Original: Riley
  - Edit: Riley [Last Name]
  - Reason: Full name is more professional; helps with identification.

Ready-to-send edited email
Subject: Request for 48‚ÄëHour Extension: Research Brief due September 28
Dear Professor Ahmed,
I am writing to request a 48‚Äëhour extension on the research brief due September 28. I have completed most of the reading and need additional time to integrate sources and finalize citations. If approved, I will submit by September 30 at 11:59 p.m. Thank you for your consideration.
Best regards,
Riley [Last Name]
[Course Name and Section]
[University Email] | [Optional Student ID]

Would you like me to customize the subject line, add course details, or adjust the tone to be slightly warmer or more formal? I can also deliver a version without the optional signature details if you prefer."
