    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your paragraph and goals. I‚Äôll verify British English spelling and punctuation, fix any minor grammar issues, highlight UK vs US differences, and offer formatting tips suitable for a UK teacher. Before I begin: do you want to keep the past-tense reflective tone (‚ÄúI realised‚Ä¶ was‚Ä¶‚Äù) or would you prefer a present-perfect version (‚ÄúI‚Äôve realised‚Ä¶ is‚Ä¶‚Äù) for immediacy? I‚Äôll provide suggestions for both so you can choose.

Overview of editorial guidance
- I‚Äôll review each sentence line-by-line for spelling (UK vs US), punctuation, and minor grammar.
- I‚Äôll flag optional style tweaks that could refine clarity or tone, without changing your voice.
- I‚Äôll include UK formatting guidance for a short reflective paragraph addressed to a teacher.

Overall Feedback
- The paragraph is clear, calm, and reflective‚Äîwell suited to a UK teacher audience.
- Your British spellings are consistent and correct (realised, favourite, programme, organise, colour-coded).
- Punctuation and sentence structure are sound. Only optional refinements are worth considering (e.g., tense alignment or word choice like achievable vs possible).

Spelling Edits (line-by-line with UK vs US notes)
1) ‚ÄúI realised that my favourite part of the programme was how it helped me organise my thoughts.‚Äù
   - realised (UK) vs realized (US): correct UK.
   - favourite (UK) vs favorite (US): correct UK.
   - programme (UK, for a course/series) vs program (US): correct UK.
   - organise (UK -ise) vs organize (US -ize): correct UK.
   - No spelling changes needed.

2) ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt glamorous, but the colour-coded cards made revision feel possible again.‚Äù
   - colour-coded (UK) vs color-coded (US): correct UK.
   - No spelling changes needed.

3) ‚ÄúIf I can keep this habit, I‚Äôll be more consistent next term.‚Äù
   - No UK/US spelling differences present; all correct.

Grammar Edits (line-by-line with reasoning)
1) ‚ÄúI realised that my favourite part of the programme was how it helped me organise my thoughts.‚Äù
   - Grammatically correct. Optional: ‚Äúthe way it helped me organise my thoughts‚Äù can sound slightly more formal than ‚Äúhow,‚Äù but both are fine.
   - Optional tense alignment (if you want immediacy): ‚ÄúI‚Äôve realised that my favourite part of the programme is the way it helps me organise my thoughts.‚Äù This shifts to present-perfect and present tense to emphasise a current insight.

2) ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt glamorous, but the colour-coded cards made revision feel possible again.‚Äù
   - Correct use of comma before ‚Äúbut‚Äù to join two independent clauses.
   - Optional word choice: ‚Äúachievable‚Äù or ‚Äúmanageable‚Äù may be slightly stronger than ‚Äúpossible,‚Äù as they imply practicality rather than mere possibility.

3) ‚ÄúIf I can keep this habit, I‚Äôll be more consistent next term.‚Äù
   - Correct comma after the introductory clause.
   - If you mean commitment rather than ability, consider: ‚ÄúIf I keep this habit, I‚Äôll be more consistent next term.‚Äù Using ‚Äúcan‚Äù emphasises ability; omitting it emphasises intention.

Structural Suggestions
- For a short reflective paragraph, your three-sentence structure is effective: past insight ‚Üí practical method ‚Üí forward-looking goal.
- If you prefer a tighter tense flow, consider making all sentences present-focused: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve realised‚Ä¶ It isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶ If I keep‚Ä¶‚Äù. This presents the reflection as current and ongoing. Otherwise, the original past-to-future progression is perfectly fine.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Strengthen specificity slightly: ‚Äúcolour-coded cards‚Äù could briefly note purpose (e.g., ‚Äúcolour-coded cue cards for topics and formulas‚Äù) if you want to show method, but this is optional given the paragraph‚Äôs brevity.
- Word choice: swap ‚Äúpossible‚Äù for ‚Äúachievable‚Äù or ‚Äúmanageable‚Äù to underscore practicality.

Formatting Guidance (UK conventions)
- Paragraph length: one compact paragraph is appropriate; keep it to 3‚Äì5 sentences for clarity.
- Hyphenation: ‚Äúcolour-coded‚Äù is correctly hyphenated as a compound adjective before the noun.
- Apostrophes: ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt‚Äù and ‚ÄúI‚Äôll‚Äù are correctly contracted; use smart (curly) apostrophes if typesetting permits, but straight apostrophes are fine for plain text.
- Quotation marks: use single quotes for quoted words/phrases if needed (UK convention), though none are required here.
- Spacing and punctuation: one space after full stops; avoid extra spaces before commas/full stops.
- Maintain -ise/-yse spellings consistently in future writing (organise, analyse) to match UK preference.

Would you like anything else?
- Would you like me to keep the original tense, or rewrite with the present-perfect immediacy?
- Do you prefer ‚Äúachievable‚Äù or ‚Äúmanageable‚Äù instead of ‚Äúpossible‚Äù?

Offer to generate the edited text
- Minimal-edit version (keeping your tone and structure, with one optional word choice):
  ‚ÄúI realised that my favourite part of the programme was how it helped me organise my thoughts. It wasn‚Äôt glamorous, but the colour-coded cards made revision feel achievable again. If I can keep this habit, I‚Äôll be more consistent next term.‚Äù
- Present-focused alternative (for immediacy and tense alignment):
  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve realised that my favourite part of the programme is the way it helps me organise my thoughts. It isn‚Äôt glamorous, but the colour-coded cards make revision feel achievable again. If I keep this habit, I‚Äôll be more consistent next term.‚Äù

Tell me which version you prefer, and I can finalise and format it accordingly."

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your goals and the excerpt. I can help clean up comma splices and run-ons, strengthen the thesis and paragraphing, fix any spelling, and provide MLA basics. Before we finalize, a couple quick clarifying questions:
- Is first-person acceptable for your assignment, or would your teacher prefer a more objective tone (third person)?
- Do you want a single, concise paragraph here, or are you building toward a full compare‚Äìcontrast essay with multiple body paragraphs?
- Would you prefer a point-by-point structure (compare each criterion across both formats in the same paragraph) or a block structure (all e-book points first, then all print-book points)?

Overview of what I‚Äôll do:
- Make precise, line-by-line edits to fix comma splices, run-ons, and clarity.
- Offer two revised versions: one minimal edit (keeps your voice) and one more formal, thesis-forward.
- Recommend a compare‚Äìcontrast structure (block vs point-by-point) tailored to your content.
- Provide MLA formatting guidance for a high school English submission.

Categorized feedback

Overall Feedback
- Your comparisons are relevant and concrete (portability, eye comfort, annotations, batteries). To strengthen the analytical tone, clarify the thesis so it indicates your criteria and the conditional judgment (e.g., convenience vs deep reading).
- Eliminate comma splices by using colons/semicolons appropriately or by splitting into separate sentences.
- Tighten phrasing and make subject references explicit (‚Äúit loses meaning‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúthe highlighting loses its meaning‚Äù).

Spelling Edits
- ebooks ‚Üí e-books
  Reason: Hyphenation is standard in formal writing when ‚Äúe-‚Äù is used as a prefix.
- don‚Äôt ‚Üí do not
  Reason: MLA essays generally avoid contractions for a more formal tone.

Grammar Edits (line-by-line with reasoning)
1) Original: ‚ÄúWhile ebooks are convenient because you can carry many in one device, print books have advantages too, they are easier on the eyes and don‚Äôt need batteries.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúWhile e-books are convenient because you can carry many on one device, print books also have advantages: they are easier on the eyes and do not need batteries.‚Äù
   Why: 
   - Changed ‚Äúebooks‚Äù to ‚Äúe-books‚Äù (spelling/formality).
   - ‚Äúin one device‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúon one device‚Äù (correct preposition).
   - ‚Äúprint books have advantages too, they are‚Ä¶‚Äù was a comma splice. Replaced with a colon to introduce the list of advantages.
   - Removed contraction for MLA formality.

2) Original: ‚ÄúAlso I think annotations feel different, on a screen I highlight too much and it loses meaning, with paper I slow down more.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúAlso, annotations feel different: on a screen, I tend to highlight too much, and the highlighting loses its meaning; with paper, I slow down more.‚Äù
   Why:
   - Comma after the introductory adverb ‚ÄúAlso.‚Äù
   - Removed ‚ÄúI think‚Äù to reduce hedging and strengthen the analytical tone.
   - Used a colon to introduce examples and a semicolon to link two closely related independent clauses (avoids run-ons).
   - Clarified the vague pronoun ‚Äúit‚Äù to ‚Äúthe highlighting,‚Äù improving precision.

3) Original: ‚ÄúBoth formats can be good but it depends on the reader and the situation.‚Äù
   Edited: ‚ÄúUltimately, both formats can be effective, but the better choice depends on the reader and the purpose.‚Äù
   Why:
   - Added ‚ÄúUltimately‚Äù for a concluding signal.
   - Inserted a comma before ‚Äúbut‚Äù to separate independent clauses.
   - ‚Äúeffective‚Äù is slightly more formal than ‚Äúgood.‚Äù
   - ‚Äúpurpose‚Äù is more specific than ‚Äúsituation,‚Äù supporting analytical comparison.

Structural Suggestions (compare/contrast)
- Point-by-point is ideal for your criteria-driven comparison. Suggested outline:
  - Thesis: Establish conditional judgment based on purpose (portability vs deep reading).
  - Point 1: Portability ‚Äî e-books excel; print books are limited.
  - Point 2: Readability/eye comfort ‚Äî print books often easier on the eyes; screens can strain.
  - Point 3: Annotation ‚Äî screen highlighting can become excessive; paper slows you down and adds focus.
  - Point 4: Power dependence ‚Äî e-books require batteries; print books do not.
  - Conclusion: The preferable format depends on whether the goal is quick access or sustained, attentive reading.
- Block structure (all e-book points, then all print points) can work for longer essays, but with your focused criteria, point-by-point will keep comparisons clear and analytical.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Strengthen the thesis to name the criteria and the conditional choice (e.g., convenience vs comprehension).
- Maintain parallelism when listing advantages (e.g., ‚Äúeasier on the eyes and independent of batteries‚Äù).
- Consider reducing first-person if your teacher prefers objectivity: ‚ÄúOn screens, highlighting often becomes excessive‚Ä¶‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúI highlight too much.‚Äù
- Vary sentence starts (not all with ‚ÄúAlso‚Äù or ‚ÄúUltimately‚Äù) and use transitions like ‚ÄúMoreover,‚Äù ‚ÄúIn contrast,‚Äù ‚ÄúHowever.‚Äù

Formatting Guidance (MLA basics)
- Use 12-point Times New Roman, double-spaced, 1-inch margins.
- Header: Your Name, Teacher‚Äôs Name, Course, Date (in day month year), top left.
- Page numbers: Last name and page number in the upper right header.
- Title: Centered, standard capitalization, no bold/underline.
- Avoid contractions; use present tense consistently for general comparisons.
- No sources needed here‚Äîso no in-text citations or Works Cited for this excerpt.

Would you like me to keep first-person examples or shift them to a more objective tone?

Edited text options

Option A: Minimal changes (keeps your voice)
- ‚ÄúWhile e-books are convenient because you can carry many on one device, print books also have advantages: they are easier on the eyes and do not need batteries. Also, annotations feel different: on a screen, I tend to highlight too much, and the highlighting loses its meaning; with paper, I slow down more. Ultimately, both formats can be effective, but the better choice depends on the reader and the purpose.‚Äù

Option B: More formal, thesis-forward (reduced first-person)
- ‚ÄúWhile e-books offer superior portability, print books provide greater eye comfort and require no batteries. Annotations also differ across formats: on screens, highlighting often becomes excessive and loses its meaning, whereas paper annotation encourages a slower, more attentive pace. Ultimately, both formats can be effective; the better choice depends on the reader‚Äôs purpose‚Äîquick access versus deep reading.‚Äù

Would you like me to generate a point-by-point outline for a full essay based on these ideas, or further revise one of the options to fit your teacher‚Äôs preferences?"

    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your paragraph. I can provide line-by-line edits with reasoning, structural suggestions, and formatting guidance (including italics for film titles). Before I dive in, two quick questions to tailor the edit:
- Do you want the commander named, or should we keep it generic to avoid spoilers? 
- Any preferred length for the final paragraph (e.g., 4‚Äì5 sentences)?

Overview of the editorial approach
- Keep analysis in present tense (standard for film analysis).
- Improve clarity and specificity (e.g., ‚Äústorm sequence,‚Äù ‚Äúcrew‚Äôs faces,‚Äù ‚Äúmethodical problem-solving‚Äù).
- Fix article usage and verb forms, and remove comma splices.
- Strengthen the conclusion by clearly linking the craft choices to the film‚Äôs central theme without spoiling beyond the opening.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
1) Original: ‚ÄúIn the opening of The Martian, the storm scene shows how group decision under pressure can go wrong.‚Äù
   Revised: ‚ÄúIn the opening of <em>The Martian</em>, the storm sequence shows how group decision-making under pressure can falter.‚Äù
   Why:
   - Italics: Film title should be italicized.
   - Specificity: ‚Äústorm sequence‚Äù is more precise than ‚Äústorm scene.‚Äù
   - Word form: ‚Äúdecision-making‚Äù is the standard compound noun.
   - Diction: ‚Äúfalter‚Äù is a stronger, more concise verb than ‚Äúgo wrong.‚Äù

2) Original: ‚ÄúCommander makes fast call and it seems rational, but the camera shows doubt on faces which builds tension.‚Äù
   Revised: ‚ÄúThe commander makes a quick call that seems rational, but the camera lingers on the crew‚Äôs doubtful faces, building tension.‚Äù
   Why:
   - Article usage: Add ‚ÄúThe‚Äù before ‚Äúcommander.‚Äù
   - Diction: ‚Äúquick‚Äù is more natural than ‚Äúfast‚Äù for decisions.
   - Sentence structure: ‚Äúthat seems‚Äù integrates the clause smoothly; ‚Äúlingers‚Äù is a more vivid verb for camera behavior.
   - Specificity: ‚Äúcrew‚Äôs doubtful faces‚Äù clarifies whose faces.
   - Flow: Replace ‚Äúwhich builds tension‚Äù with a participial phrase (‚Äúbuilding tension‚Äù) for concision.

3) Original: ‚ÄúThe sound mix is loud and harsh, it put us in chaos.‚Äù
   Revised: ‚ÄúThe loud, harsh sound mix plunges us into chaos.‚Äù
   Why:
   - Tense consistency: Use present tense (‚Äúplunges‚Äù) for film analysis.
   - Comma splice fix: Turn two independent clauses into one clean sentence.
   - Diction: ‚Äúplunges‚Äù is vivid and precise.

4) Original: ‚ÄúThis sets up the theme of survival through careful planning later.‚Äù
   Revised: ‚ÄúThis opening also establishes the film‚Äôs central theme: survival through methodical problem‚Äësolving.‚Äù
   Why:
   - Diction: ‚Äúestablishes‚Äù is stronger than ‚Äúsets up.‚Äù
   - Specificity: ‚Äúmethodical problem‚Äësolving‚Äù is more precise than ‚Äúcareful planning.‚Äù
   - Clarity: Avoid vague ‚Äúlater‚Äù; state the thematic focus directly.

Overall Feedback
- Your focus on how visuals and sound shape the tension is strong. The edits sharpen terminology (‚Äúsequence,‚Äù ‚Äúdecision-making,‚Äù ‚Äúlingers,‚Äù ‚Äúplunges‚Äù) and maintain present-tense consistency.
- The strengthened conclusion clearly ties the scene‚Äôs craft to the film‚Äôs core theme without spoiling plot developments.

Spelling Edits
- No spelling errors detected.
- Minor word-choice refinements for clarity (e.g., ‚Äúdecision-making,‚Äù ‚Äúquick,‚Äù ‚Äúsequence‚Äù).

Grammar Edits
- Article usage: Add ‚ÄúThe‚Äù before ‚Äúcommander.‚Äù
- Tense consistency: Use present tense throughout (‚Äúputs‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúplunges‚Äù).
- Comma splice: Replace ‚Äúis loud and harsh, it put‚Äù with a single clause or two sentences.
- Noun form: ‚Äúgroup decision‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúgroup decision-making.‚Äù
- Pronoun specificity: ‚Äúfaces‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúcrew‚Äôs faces‚Äù clarifies the subject.

Structural Suggestions
- Keep a clear progression: context of the scene ‚Üí leader‚Äôs decision ‚Üí camera‚Äôs perspective ‚Üí sound design ‚Üí thematic implication.
- Consider a slightly stronger concluding sentence that connects the opening‚Äôs urgency to the film‚Äôs ongoing emphasis on strategy over impulse (without detailing later plot).
- If allowed, naming the commander can add specificity; if not, ‚Äúthe commander‚Äù is fine for a concise analysis.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Add one concrete craft detail for texture (e.g., ‚Äúclose-ups through helmets,‚Äù ‚Äúwind and alarm layering‚Äù); still spoiler-safe and within the opening‚Äôs timeframe.
- Briefly contrast ‚Äúrational in the moment‚Äù with ‚Äúvisible uncertainty,‚Äù highlighting the tension between protocol and human doubt.

Formatting Guidance
- Film titles: Italicize with HTML tags in a web post (e.g., <em>The Martian</em>).
- Keep analysis in present tense.
- Use short, clean sentences (4‚Äì6 lines total) to suit a class blog layout.

Suggested stronger concluding options (pick one)
- ‚ÄúBy foregrounding uncertainty amid urgency, the film primes us to value strategy over impulse in the challenges that follow.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúThe sequence teaches us to watch for careful, methodical choices as the key to survival.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúFrom the first minutes, the film argues that survival depends less on bold moves than on disciplined problem‚Äësolving.‚Äù

Would you like me to generate the edited paragraph with italics and your preferred conclusion? Here‚Äôs a concise version that incorporates all changes:

Edited paragraph (web‚Äëready)
‚ÄúIn the opening of <em>The Martian</em>, the storm sequence shows how group decision-making under pressure can falter. The commander makes a quick call that seems rational, but the camera lingers on the crew‚Äôs doubtful faces, building tension. The loud, harsh sound mix plunges us into chaos. This opening also establishes the film‚Äôs central theme: survival through methodical problem‚Äësolving.‚Äù

If you want, I can swap in one of the stronger concluding options or add a single craft detail for extra specificity while staying spoiler-safe."

text: Ms. Johnson, a veteran and math teacher, started the after-school coding club to help students who felt left out of tech. ‚ÄúEverybody can learn to code,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúwe just need a place to try and fail safely.‚Äù The club has students from different backgrounds and abilities and they pair up to solve small problems. Last week they built an app that shows bus schedules, it was buggy but then they fixed it together. The room feels like a lab and a living room at once.",
    "scenario": "",
    "generation": 0,
    "testuid": "baseline-test-m2929uvyl",
    "baseline": true,
    "inverse": false,
    "groundtruthScore": 90,
    "groundtruthModel": "gpt-5-2025-08-07",
    "groundtruth": "Thanks for sharing your goals and the draft. I‚Äôll focus on fixing punctuation and capitalization, improving clarity and concision, keeping quotes verbatim, and ensuring respectful, AP-style presentation for school newspaper readers.

Quick check: Would you like to keep the courtesy title ‚ÄúMs.‚Äù (common in school papers) or follow strict AP style and use the last name only (‚ÄúJohnson‚Äù)? Also, do you want to include her first name anywhere?

Overview of the approach
- Line-by-line edits focused on punctuation, capitalization, clarity, and concision, with reasoning for each change.
- Respectful wording for references to backgrounds and abilities.
- AP-style guidance for quotes, attribution, titles, numbers, and hyphenation.
- Structural suggestions to strengthen the article‚Äôs flow for a community profile.

Overall Feedback
- Your piece has a clear, positive tone, a strong quote, and a vivid closing image. To improve readability and professionalism for a school newspaper, tighten sentences, avoid comma splices, use precise terms (e.g., ‚Äútechnology‚Äù instead of ‚Äútech‚Äù), and maintain consistent tense. Format the quotes in AP style while keeping the interviewee‚Äôs words verbatim.
- Consider adding a brief context sentence (school name, when the club started, meeting details) to help readers understand the club‚Äôs impact.

Spelling Edits
- ‚Äútech‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äútechnology‚Äù
  - Reason: ‚Äútechnology‚Äù is more formal and appropriate for a school newspaper; ‚Äútech‚Äù reads as colloquial.
- ‚Äúafter-school‚Äù is correctly hyphenated. No change needed.
- ‚Äúapp‚Äù is acceptable in AP style. No change needed.

Grammar Edits (line-by-line with suggested revisions and reasoning)
1) Original: ‚ÄúMs. Johnson, a veteran and math teacher, started the after-school coding club to help students who felt left out of tech.‚Äù
   - Suggested: ‚ÄúMs. Johnson, a veteran and math teacher, started the after-school coding club to support students who feel left out of technology.‚Äù
   - Reasoning: ‚ÄúSupport‚Äù is concise and respectful; ‚Äúfeel‚Äù maintains present-tense for an ongoing situation; ‚Äútechnology‚Äù is more formal than ‚Äútech.‚Äù

2) Original (quote): ‚ÄúEverybody can learn to code,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúwe just need a place to try and fail safely.‚Äù
   - Suggested formatting (keeping words verbatim): ‚ÄúEverybody can learn to code,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe just need a place to try and fail safely.‚Äù
   - Reasoning: Breaks a comma splice into two sentences, which is clearer and follows AP-style quoting with attribution.

3) Original: ‚ÄúThe club has students from different backgrounds and abilities and they pair up to solve small problems.‚Äù
   - Suggested: ‚ÄúThe club includes students with diverse backgrounds and abilities, and members pair up to solve small problems.‚Äù
   - Reasoning: ‚ÄúIncludes‚Äù is more precise; ‚Äúwith diverse backgrounds and abilities‚Äù improves parallel structure and tone; ‚Äúmembers‚Äù avoids repetitive ‚Äúthey‚Äù and clarifies who pairs up.

4) Original: ‚ÄúLast week they built an app that shows bus schedules, it was buggy but then they fixed it together.‚Äù
   - Suggested: ‚ÄúLast week, they built an app that shows bus schedules. It was buggy at first, but they fixed it together.‚Äù
   - Reasoning: Fixes a comma splice by making two sentences; adds a comma after the introductory phrase; ‚Äúat first‚Äù is concise and improves flow.

5) Original: ‚ÄúThe room feels like a lab and a living room at once.‚Äù
   - Suggested: ‚ÄúThe room feels like both a lab and a living room.‚Äù
   - Reasoning: ‚ÄúBoth ‚Ä¶ and ‚Ä¶‚Äù is concise and clearer than ‚Äúat once.‚Äù

Structural Suggestions
- Lead/nut graf: Add one sentence at the top with school name and a brief purpose (‚ÄúThe coding club at [School Name], started in [semester/year], welcomes students who want to explore programming in a supportive setting.‚Äù).
- Context: Consider one sentence explaining how often the club meets or the number of participants (AP style: use numerals for 10 and above).
- Flow: Current sequence works well‚Äîintroduction ‚Üí quote ‚Üí description ‚Üí example ‚Üí image. The example (‚Äúbus schedules‚Äù app) nicely shows collaboration; keep it immediately after the quote for impact.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Attribution variety: After first mention, use ‚ÄúJohnson said‚Äù instead of ‚Äúshe said‚Äù to align with AP style and clarity (especially if multiple speakers appear later).
- Specifics: If available, add details like meeting times (‚ÄúWednesdays after school‚Äù), location (room number), or outcomes (e.g., whether the app is used by students). This deepens the profile without changing the quotes.
- Respectful portrayal: ‚ÄúDiverse backgrounds and abilities‚Äù is good; avoid phrasing that implies deficit (e.g., ‚Äústruggling kids‚Äù). Your current language is respectful‚Äîjust keep it consistent.

Formatting Guidance (AP style)
- Quotes and attribution:
  - Use double quotation marks.
  - Place periods and commas inside quotation marks.
  - Preferred format when splitting a quote: ‚ÄúSentence,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúSecond sentence.‚Äù
  - Keep the interviewee‚Äôs words exactly as spoken; you may break long quotes around the attribution without changing the words.
- Courtesy titles:
  - AP style typically avoids courtesy titles; use ‚ÄúJohnson‚Äù after first reference. If your school‚Äôs style uses ‚ÄúMs.‚Äù for teachers, keep it consistently.
- Numbers:
  - Spell out one through nine; use numerals for 10 and above.
  - Use numerals for time and dates (e.g., 3 p.m., Sept. 21).
- Hyphenation:
  - ‚Äúafter-school‚Äù is hyphenated when used as a compound modifier (‚Äúafter-school coding club‚Äù).
- Job descriptions:
  - Lowercase generic titles after names (‚Äúmath teacher‚Äù) unless used before a name as a formal title (e.g., ‚ÄúPrincipal Maria Lopez‚Äù).
- Composition:
  - Keep paragraphs concise; one to three sentences per graf is fine for school newspaper style.

Would you like me to incorporate these edits into a clean, AP-style version?

Proposed edited version (quotes kept verbatim):
Ms. Johnson, a veteran and math teacher, started the after-school coding club to support students who feel left out of technology. ‚ÄúEverybody can learn to code,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe just need a place to try and fail safely.‚Äù The club includes students with diverse backgrounds and abilities, and members pair up to solve small problems. Last week, they built an app that shows bus schedules. It was buggy at first, but they fixed it together. The room feels like both a lab and a living room.

If you confirm how you want to handle the courtesy title and whether to add school-specific details, I can finalize this for publication."
  }
]

Overall Feedback

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚Äúalot‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúa lot‚Äù (spelling): ‚Äúalot‚Äù is nonstandard; the correct form is two words.  
‚Ä¢ ‚Äúeffecting‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúaffecting‚Äù (word choice/usage): ‚Äúto affect‚Äù means to influence, whereas ‚Äúeffect‚Äù is usually a noun meaning result.  
‚Ä¢ ‚Äúits‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúit‚Äôs‚Äù (spelling/grammar): you need the contraction ‚Äúit is,‚Äù so include an apostrophe.

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúWeather is affecting farmers a lot.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúWeather is affecting farmers a lot.‚Äù (grammar/clarity): ensure subject-verb clarity; ‚Äúweather‚Äù needs no article here.

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if its good.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs good.‚Äù (grammar): add apostrophe for contraction.  

Structural Suggestions

  ‚ÄúWeather is affecting farmers a lot, and the data I‚Äôve collected are scattered; I plan to add more later.‚Äù

Based on your goal to strengthen thesis clarity and persuasive impact for a high-school teacher audience, I‚Äôll focus on sharpening your central claim, improving logical flow with stronger transitions, and ensuring each sentence supports your argument consistently.

Overall Feedback

Right now, the three sentences read like notes rather than a cohesive introduction. You need a precise thesis that previews your supporting points, plus smoother links between ideas. With targeted edits, you can turn this into a compelling opening that convinces your reader of both the problem and your solution.

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ No spelling errors detected in the provided text. (Issue: spelling ‚Äì your word choices are all correctly spelled.)

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ Line 2: ‚ÄúHowever my thesis is vague‚Äù ‚Üí add a comma after ‚ÄúHowever‚Äù: ‚ÄúHowever, my thesis is vague.‚Äù (Issue: punctuation ‚Äì introductory adverb ‚ÄòHowever‚Äô should be followed by a comma.)  
‚Ä¢ Line 3: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt consistently support claims.‚Äù ‚Üí consider ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt consistently back up my claims.‚Äù (Issue: word choice ‚Äì ‚Äúback up‚Äù clarifies that you need evidence; maintains conversational tone.)  
‚Ä¢ Throughout: replace contractions (‚Äúdon‚Äôt‚Äù) with either full forms (‚Äúdo not‚Äù) or remain consistent based on your tone. (Issue: style ‚Äì choose one form for formality consistency.)

Structural Suggestions

  ‚Äì For example, ‚ÄúAdopting school uniforms in our district will reduce bullying, foster a stronger sense of community, and help students focus on learning.‚Äù

Based on your goal to improve grammar and clarity in a short reflective essay for a teacher audience, this edit focuses on correcting verb agreement and tense consistency, fixing awkward modifiers and run-ons, and suggesting ways to enhance flow and reflection.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft clearly shows you met your project goal, but a few grammar slips and structure issues make it harder to follow. You can strengthen clarity by ensuring verbs agree with their subjects, keeping tenses consistent, fixing dangling modifiers, and breaking up run-on sentences. Also consider adding brief reflections on what you learned.

Spelling Edits

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe results shows that I was successful in the project.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúThe results show that I was successful in the project.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: subject-verb agreement. ‚ÄúResults‚Äù is plural, so the verb must be ‚Äúshow‚Äù (grammar).

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI was working on the report and finish it yesterday.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúI was working on the report and finished it yesterday.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: parallel structure and tense consistency. Both verbs should match in tense, so use ‚Äúfinished‚Äù (tense consistency).

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúRunning quickly, the finish line seemed far.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúAs I ran quickly, the finish line seemed far away.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: dangling modifier. The original makes the ‚Äúfinish line‚Äù do the running. By naming ‚ÄúI‚Äù as the runner, the meaning is clear (clarity).

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe team were excited, we celebrated and it was great.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúThe team was excited. We celebrated, and it was great.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: subject-verb agreement (‚Äúteam‚Äù is singular in American English) and comma splice. Splitting into two sentences or using a semicolon prevents the run-on (grammar, style).

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Begin with a brief context sentence. For example, start with ‚ÄúWhen I completed the final draft of my project report, I felt a mix of relief and pride.‚Äù This sets up what follows (coherence).  
‚Ä¢ Combine or expand reflections. After noting success, add a sentence on what you learned: ‚ÄúThis process taught me the importance of time management and peer feedback.‚Äù This deepens the essay‚Äôs reflective purpose (development).  
‚Ä¢ End with a concluding thought. Rather than stopping at celebration, finish by linking back to your growth: ‚ÄúOverall, the experience has made me more confident in handling complex tasks.‚Äù A conclusion gives closure (flow).

Opportunities for Improvement

‚Ä¢ Transitions: Use words such as ‚Äúthen,‚Äù ‚Äúnext,‚Äù or ‚Äúfinally‚Äù to guide the reader through your steps.

‚Ä¢ Spacing: Leave a blank line between paragraphs for readability.  
‚Ä¢ If you reference any sources or feedback, use a simple citation style (teacher‚Äôs preference) like parentheses or footnotes.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft identifies key issues with the experiment and points out limitations, which is a good start. To strengthen it for an academic audience, tighten the language by removing casual phrases (‚Äúkind of‚Äù), fix subject-verb agreement, and replace vague judgments (‚Äúit‚Äôs good‚Äù) with precise evaluations. Reorganize sentences so that related ideas (data issues, recording methods, limitations) are grouped together, and add brief explanations or examples to support your claims.

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ In ‚ÄúThe experiment was sucssesful‚Ä¶‚Äù (line 1): change ‚Äúsucssesful‚Äù to ‚Äúsuccessful.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue type: spelling. ‚ÄúSuccessful‚Äù is the correct spelling.  

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ In ‚Äúwe was recording at different times‚Äù (line 2): change ‚Äúwas‚Äù to ‚Äúwere.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ In ‚ÄúThe data is inconsistent‚Äù (line 2): consider ‚ÄúThe data are inconsistent.‚Äù

Spelling Edits

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI am watching the waves‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúI watched the waves‚Äù  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: shift present continuous to simple past for a uniform past narrative.  

‚Ä¢ ‚Äúlater I will wrote about it‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúlater I will write about it‚Äù or ‚Äúlater I wrote about it‚Äù  
  Issue: incorrect verb form. Rationale: ‚Äúwrote‚Äù is past; with ‚Äúwill,‚Äù you need the base form ‚Äúwrite.‚Äù If you want a pure past narrative, choose ‚Äúlater I wrote about it.‚Äù  

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI'm gonna add more details‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúI added more details‚Äù or ‚ÄúI was going to add more details‚Äù  
  Issue: tense and style. Rationale: replace slang and match past tense (‚Äúadded‚Äù) or use the full phrase ‚Äúgoing to‚Äù with past (‚ÄúI was going to add‚Äù).  

‚Ä¢ ‚Äúit felt awesome, but the structure is all over the place‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúit felt awesome, but the structure was all over the place‚Äù  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: change present ‚Äúis‚Äù to past ‚Äúwas.‚Äù  

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI start with the ending‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúI started with the ending‚Äù  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: change present ‚Äústart‚Äù to past ‚Äústarted.‚Äù  

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe style switches between casual and formal.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúThe style switched between casual and formal.‚Äù  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: change present ‚Äúswitches‚Äù to past ‚Äúswitched.‚Äù

Structural Suggestions
‚Ä¢ Reorder chronologically: begin with ‚ÄúYesterday I walked to the beach and watched the waves,‚Äù then explain what you did next. Rationale: a clear timeline helps readers follow the story.  
‚Ä¢ Group your writing reflections at the end: move comments about structure and tone after the action. Rationale: separating the narrative from your analysis keeps the story focused and then allows a tidy reflection.  
‚Ä¢ Consider combining short, related sentences: for example, merge details about adding material and feeling excitement (‚ÄúI added more details because I felt awesome‚Äù) for stronger flow. Rationale: avoids choppy rhythm and reinforces connection between ideas.

Opportunities for Improvement
‚Ä¢ Add sensory details: describe the color of the water, the sound of waves, or the smell of salt air. Rationale: engages readers and brings the scene to life.  
‚Ä¢ Use transitions: words like ‚Äúthen,‚Äù ‚Äúafterward,‚Äù or ‚Äúlater‚Äù guide readers through the sequence of events. Rationale: makes the narrative smoother.  
‚Ä¢ Decide on a tone: if you choose a conversational style, keep contractions like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Äù but use standard words; if you choose formal, avoid slang entirely. Rationale: consistency in voice builds reader trust.  
‚Ä¢ Show rather than tell: instead of ‚Äúit felt awesome,‚Äù illustrate why‚Äî‚ÄúThe sun warmed my back as I watched the waves crash.‚Äù Rationale: creates a vivid picture and deeper connection.

Formatting Guidance
‚Ä¢ Break into paragraphs: start a new paragraph for the beach scene, another for your writing process, and a final one for reflections.  
‚Ä¢ Indent or add a blank line between paragraphs to signal shifts in focus.  
‚Ä¢ If this is a submitted essay, double-space your text and use a standard font (Times New Roman, 12 pt) with one-inch margins.  
‚Ä¢ For the title, center it and use sentence capitalization (e.g., ‚ÄúA Day at the Beach‚Äù).

I will look at how you introduce your research question, order background, methods, results, and conclusion, and eliminate duplicated points. Overall Feedback  
- Your main challenge is the order of sections. Background information and methods appear too late, while the research question is introduced after results.  
- You also repeat points in background and conclusion, which weakens your summary‚Äôs clarity.  
- By moving each element into the typical IMRaD (Introduction, Methods, Results, and Discussion/Conclusion) order, you‚Äôll create a smoother, more professional structure.

Spelling Edits  
- None detected. Your text does not contain any misspelled words.

Grammar Edits  
- ‚ÄúThe results section lists three key findings, then I introduce my research question.‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Issue type: tense consistency and point of view  
  ‚Ä¢ Rationale: You switch between third-person present (‚Äúlists‚Äù) and first-person present (‚ÄúI introduce‚Äù). Choose one perspective and keep tenses parallel.  
  ‚Ä¢ Suggested fix (third person): ‚ÄúThe results section lists three key findings, then introduces the research question.‚Äù  

- ‚ÄúBackground information appears after the conclusion, and some duplicated points appear in both sections.‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Issue type: wordiness  
  ‚Ä¢ Rationale: The phrase ‚Äúappear after‚Äù and ‚Äúappear in both‚Äù is repetitive. You can condense for clarity.  
  ‚Ä¢ Suggested fix: ‚ÄúBackground information follows the conclusion, and some points are duplicated in both sections.‚Äù  

Structural Suggestions  
- Move your research question and background to the very beginning (after a brief intro or title).  
  ‚Ä¢ Benefit: Readers understand why you did the study before seeing your findings.  
- Position the methods section immediately after background.  
  ‚Ä¢ Benefit: Explains how you obtained results before presenting them, which is standard in research summaries.  
- Follow methods with results (your three key findings).  
  ‚Ä¢ Benefit: Keeps the logical flow‚Äî‚Äúhere‚Äôs how we did it‚Äù leads to ‚Äúhere‚Äôs what we found.‚Äù  
- End with a concise conclusion that does not re-state background details.  
  ‚Ä¢ Benefit: Avoids duplication and reinforces only your main takeaway.

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add a brief introductory sentence that states the study‚Äôs purpose before your research question.  
- Use transitional phrases such as ‚ÄúFirst,‚Äù ‚ÄúNext,‚Äù and ‚ÄúFinally‚Äù to guide the reader through each section.  
- When summarizing your conclusion, highlight implications or future directions to give it more depth.

Formatting Guidance  
- Use clear headings: Introduction (or Background), Methods, Results, Conclusion.  
- Insert a blank line between each section to improve readability.  
- If required, follow your instructor‚Äôs preferred citation style (e.g., APA) for any in-text references in the background.

- No misspellings detected. (Spelling) Your text is free of spelling errors.

Structural Suggestions

  Recommendation: Break this into separate paragraphs, each focused on one benefit (health, community, property values). Start each with a topic sentence, follow with an example or statistic, then use a transition.  
  How it helps: Clear organization and evidence make each point stand out and feel credible.  

- Transitions: Line 3 (‚ÄúTransitions between paragraphs are weak‚Ä¶‚Äù)  
  Recommendation: At the end of each paragraph, add a linking sentence‚Äîe.g., ‚ÄúBeyond health improvements, parks also boost our local economy.‚Äù  
  How it helps: Readers will move smoothly from one idea to the next without feeling jolted.  

- Conclusion: Add a final paragraph that restates your main point, sums up key benefits in one or two sentences, and issues a specific call to action (‚ÄúAsk your neighbor to join you at the council meeting on May 5th and speak up for new parks.‚Äù).

Opportunities for Improvement

This feedback focuses on aligning your short fiction scene with your goals: maintaining a reflective, slightly whimsical first-person voice while improving tense consistency, sharpening clarity in descriptions, and correcting dialogue punctuation. I‚Äôll provide line-by-line notes, pacing and structure suggestions, and show-vs-tell guidance, all tailored for a teen literary magazine submission in standard manuscript format.

Overall Feedback  
Your scene has a charming, immersive start, but shifts in tense and a string of short sentences sometimes interrupt the dreamy, reflective tone you‚Äôre aiming for. Strengthening sensory details and varying sentence length will heighten the whimsy. Clear, consistent tense and polished dialogue punctuation will help readers stay grounded in your narrator‚Äôs perspective and feel more connected to the moment at the arcade.

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ No spelling errors detected. (Spelling: the text‚Äôs word choices are correct.)

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI walk into the old arcade last night‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúI walked into the old arcade last night.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: tense consistency. You mix present (‚Äúwalk‚Äù) with past (‚Äúlast night‚Äù). Changing ‚Äúwalk‚Äù to ‚Äúwalked‚Äù keeps past tense throughout the narration.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúYou coming?‚Äù Jay says, but I was already at the claw machine‚Ä¶ ‚Üí Separate into two sentences or use a semicolon. For example: ‚ÄúYou coming?‚Äù Jay says. I was already at the claw machine‚Ä¶  
  ‚Äì Issue: run-on sentence and dialogue tag punctuation. Ending the quote with a question mark should be followed by a closing quote and then a period or new sentence before continuing.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI am thinking this is silly and then the claw was moving‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúI think this is silly, and then the claw moved‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: tense consistency and clarity. Changing ‚Äúam thinking‚Äù to simple present (‚Äúthink‚Äù) or past (‚Äúthought‚Äù) and ‚Äúwas moving‚Äù to ‚Äúmoved‚Äù aligns your verbs.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe whale slips, then it slip again‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúThe whale slips, then it slips again.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: subject‚Äêverb agreement. ‚ÄúIt slip‚Äù should be ‚Äúit slips‚Äù to match singular subject ‚Äúwhale.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI drop the token. It clatters. I am thinking‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Üí consider merging: ‚ÄúI drop the token; it clatters, and I think‚Ä¶‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: choppy sentence rhythm. Using a semicolon or conjunction binds related actions for smoother flow.

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Break into paragraphs for better pacing:  
  ‚Äì Paragraph 1: station arrival and mood (lines about lights buzzing, dusty air).  
  ‚Äì Paragraph 2: Jay‚Äôs dialogue and your diversion to the claw machine.  
  ‚Äì Paragraph 3: dropping the token and the machine‚Äôs action.  
  This separation guides the reader through each beat of the scene and prevents short sentences from running together.  
‚Ä¢ Rearrange sensory details to ‚Äúshow‚Äù more: start with a small action (like flicking a coin into your palm) before describing smells. This grounds the narrator‚Äôs body in the scene, then expands to scent and sound.  
‚Ä¢ Introduce internal reflection after action: rather than ‚ÄúI am thinking this is silly‚Äù in the middle, you might pause after the claw moves to let the narrator‚Äôs thoughts unfold, then return to action. That variation pulls readers deeper into the reflective voice.

Opportunities for Improvement  
‚Ä¢ Show vs. tell: replace ‚Äúthe air smells of dust and coins‚Äù with a brief image, e.g., ‚ÄúI can taste the powdery dust on my tongue and hear the soft jingle of loose change.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ Emotional stakes: hint at why the plush whale matters‚Äîdoes it remind the narrator of someone or something? A sentence or two of backstory will deepen engagement.  
‚Ä¢ Vary sentence length: mix short, punchy lines with longer, flowing ones to reflect that whimsical tone and keep readers on their toes.

Formatting Guidance  
‚Ä¢ Use standard manuscript format: 12-point Courier or Times New Roman, double-spaced, one-inch margins.  
‚Ä¢ Dialogue formatting: start a new line each time the speaker changes.  
‚Ä¢ Page header: include your last name/scene title and page number in the upper right.  
‚Ä¢ Indent first line of each paragraph by ¬Ω inch‚Äîdon‚Äôt add extra spaces between paragraphs in double-spaced prose.

Based on your goals for scientific clarity, reduced passive voice, consistent tense, and improved figure/table references, I‚Äôll focus on refining active phrasing, unifying verb tenses, tightening your explanations, and ensuring APA-style headings, captions, and unit formatting.

Overall Feedback  
- You explain collision theory and your results clearly, but several sentences rely on passive voice or mix tenses, which can distract a reader.  
- Switching to active constructions and consistent present tense (for theory) or past tense (for completed experiments) will improve readability.  
- Precise wording in figure/table references and proper unit formatting will meet APA conventions.  
- A more formal style‚Äîavoiding informal phrases like ‚Äúkind of steep‚Äù‚Äîwill suit a high-school chemistry teacher audience.

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ No spelling errors detected. All scientific and common terms are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe rate of reaction is being affected by temperature according to the collision theory.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Revised: ‚ÄúAccording to collision theory, reaction rate increases as temperature rises.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: passive voice and wordiness; switched to active voice and concise phrasing.  

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúIt is believed that higher temperature increases kinetic energy and thus more effective collisions occurs.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Revised: ‚ÄúHigher temperature increases kinetic energy, leading to more effective collisions.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: passive construction (‚ÄúIt is believed‚Äù), subject‚Äìverb disagreement (‚Äúcollisions occurs‚Äù); corrected to active voice and fixed agreement.  

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe solution was heated to 30C, 40C, and 50C and the time to color change were recorded as 45s, 31s, and 19s respectively (see table 1).‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Revised: ‚ÄúWe heated the solution to 30 ¬∞C, 40 ¬∞C, and 50 ¬∞C, and recorded the time to color change as 45 s, 31 s, and 19 s, respectively (see Table 1).‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issues: mixed singular/plural (‚Äútime ‚Ä¶ were‚Äù), passive voice; missing degree symbol and space before units; ‚Äútable 1‚Äù should be ‚ÄúTable 1‚Äù in APA.  

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThere is an apparent trend showing rate goes up when temperature was raised.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Revised: ‚ÄúThe reaction rate increases as temperature increases.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issues: mixed tenses (‚Äúgoes up‚Äù vs. ‚Äúwas raised‚Äù); informal phrasing (‚Äúgoes up‚Äù); simplified to active present-tense statement of trend.  

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúFigure 2 shows the line of best fit which seems kind of steep.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Revised: ‚ÄúFigure 2 shows a steep slope for the line of best fit.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issues: informal phrase ‚Äúkind of steep‚Äù; clarified ‚Äúslope‚Äù and removed conversational tone.

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Combine theory and mechanism: Merge your two introductory sentences into one clear statement of principle (as shown above). This improves flow by introducing the key idea up front.  
‚Ä¢ Results paragraph order: First reference Table 1 immediately after describing the temperatures, then list the times. This groups related information and helps readers locate details faster.  
‚Ä¢ Add a brief concluding sentence in Results: After describing Figure 2, note what the slope indicates (for example, higher rate sensitivity), to close the paragraph with interpretation.

Opportunities for Improvement  
‚Ä¢ Define variables or acronyms on first use (e.g., ‚Äúreaction rate (k)‚Äù).  
‚Ä¢ Comment on experimental uncertainty or replicate trials to strengthen credibility.  
‚Ä¢ Include a transition sentence between Introduction and Results to describe your experimental aim.  
‚Ä¢ Consider adding numerical r¬≤ or correlation coefficients when discussing how well the line of best fit represents data.

Formatting Guidance  
‚Ä¢ APA Headings: Use bold, left-aligned Level 1 headings ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù and ‚ÄúResults‚Äù (no italics or underlines).  
‚Ä¢ Figure/Table Captions:  
  ‚Äì Table 1 caption goes above the table: ‚ÄúTable 1. Time to Color Change at Different Temperatures.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Figure 2 caption goes below the figure: ‚ÄúFigure 2. Line of Best Fit for Reaction Rate vs. Temperature.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ Units: Always include a space between number and unit (e.g., ‚Äú30 ¬∞C,‚Äù ‚Äú45 s‚Äù), and use the degree symbol (¬∞) for Celsius.  
‚Ä¢ In-text references: Capitalize ‚ÄúTable‚Äù and ‚ÄúFigure,‚Äù and italicize numbers only if required by your style guide (not in APA).

Overall Feedback  
‚Ä¢ Your thesis is clear: the New Deal reshaped the citizen‚Äìgovernment relationship despite not ending the Depression.  
‚Ä¢ Sentence-level phrasing can be tightened for precision (e.g., ‚Äúboth too much and not enough‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúexcessive and insufficient‚Äù).

‚Ä¢ Ensure footnote markers follow Chicago conventions (placed after punctuation) and include page numbers in the actual footnotes.

Spelling Edits

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ Subject-verb agreement: In ‚Äúpolicies had limits that shows the contradictions,‚Äù change shows ‚Üí show to match plural subject ‚Äúpolicies.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: subject-verb agreement; rationale: ‚Äúpolicies‚Äù is plural, so the verb must also be plural.  
‚Ä¢ Concision and clarity: ‚Äúwere criticized as being both too much and not enough‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúwere criticized as both excessive and insufficient.‚Äù

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Combine the first two sentences for a stronger topic sentence:  
  ‚Äì Move ‚ÄúHowever‚Äù into the same sentence: ‚ÄúAlthough the New Deal did not end the Great Depression, it redefined the relationship between citizens and the federal government.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Improvement: creates a single, punchy introduction that clearly states your argument.  
‚Ä¢ Tie each example back to your thesis explicitly:  
  ‚Äì After the CCC example, add a brief clause: ‚Äú‚Ä¶reinforced certain gender norms, illustrating how relief programs simultaneously advanced and constrained social roles.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Improvement: reinforces coherence by linking evidence to the central claim.  
‚Ä¢ Revise the concluding sentence to preview your paper‚Äôs next point or to encapsulate your argument‚Äôs implication:  
  ‚Äì For instance, ‚ÄúAlthough these reforms were unprecedented in scope, their limitations reveal inherent contradictions that shaped subsequent New Deal policies.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Improvement: provides a clear transition and emphasizes the argument‚Äôs broader significance.

Opportunities for Improvement  
‚Ä¢ Expand on ‚Äúreinforced certain gender norms‚Äù by briefly noting which norms or expectations were highlighted.  
‚Ä¢ Specify which domestic-worker exclusions most affected Black women (e.g., Social Security exclusion) to deepen your evidence.  
‚Ä¢ Add transitional phrases (e.g., ‚ÄúMoreover,‚Äù ‚ÄúConsequently‚Äù) between sentences to guide the reader through your logic.  
‚Ä¢ Consider integrating a brief quotation from a primary source, formatted as a Chicago footnote, to strengthen authoritative support.

Formatting Guidance  
‚Ä¢ Footnote placement: In Chicago style, place the footnote marker after the sentence‚Äôs closing punctuation (e.g., period or comma).  
‚Ä¢ Footnote content: Replace [1], [2] placeholders with full citations including author, title, page number.  
‚Ä¢ Page numbers: Ensure each footnote lists the specific page(s) you‚Äôre citing.  
‚Ä¢ Quotation format: If you introduce a direct quote under 100 words, enclose it in quotation marks and cite via footnote. For longer quotations, use block-quote formatting (indented, no quotation marks).

Overall Feedback  
‚Ä¢ Tone and voice: Shift from first-person to passive or neutral constructions (e.g., ‚Äúwas designed‚Äù instead of ‚Äúwe designed‚Äù).  
‚Ä¢ Tense consistency: Use past tense throughout to report completed work.

‚Ä¢ Structure: Clearly separate Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion to guide judges through your study.

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ No spelling errors detected. (Spelling check) All technical terms and common words are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúPlastic waste in waterways is increasing, which is why we designed a low-cost microplastic filter‚Ä¶‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Suggested: ‚ÄúPlastic waste in waterways is increasing. A low-cost microplastic filter was designed‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúWe test filtration rates and particle counts with a DIY microscope rig.‚Äù

  ‚Äì Suggested: ‚ÄúResults show a 42% mean reduction‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Ä¢ ‚Äú18% reduction in 50‚Äì100 Œºm.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Suggested: ‚Äúan 18% reduction in particles sized 50‚Äì100 micrometers (¬µm).‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: clarity (state what is reduced), unit definition, avoid dangling phrase.

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Background: Start with ‚ÄúPlastic waste in waterways is increasing.‚Äù This orients the reader immediately.  
‚Ä¢ Methods: Combine design and testing description: ‚ÄúA low-cost microplastic filter using natural fibers was designed and tested on local creek samples. Filtration rates and particle counts were measured using a do-it-yourself (DIY) microscope rig.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Improves flow by grouping all procedural information.  
‚Ä¢ Results: Present percentage reductions in one sentence: ‚ÄúResults show a 42% mean reduction in particles larger than 100 micrometers (¬µm) after 30 minutes and an 18% reduction in particles sized 50‚Äì100 ¬µm.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ Conclusion: End with limitations and future potential: ‚ÄúLimitations include inconsistent flow and clogging; however, the design can be scaled for classroom use.‚Äù

We‚Äôll preserve your personal voice and conversational tone for your high-school teacher audience.

Overall Feedback  
Your paragraph clearly conveys the challenge and growth in switching between Spanish and English. You have a strong narrative voice and honest reflections, but a few expressions still reflect Spanish structure and there are minor grammar choices that can interrupt flow. Cleaning up these moments will make your experience even more relatable and easy to follow.

Spelling Edits  
- No spelling errors found. Your words are all correctly spelled. (Issue: spelling ‚Äì no action needed.)

Grammar Edits  
- ‚ÄúMi familia and I moved to the U.S. when I was 10‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúMy family and I moved to the U.S. when I was ten.‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Issue: style/consistency. Rationale: Switching ‚ÄúMi familia‚Äù to ‚ÄúMy family‚Äù keeps it in standard American English. Spelling out ‚Äúten‚Äù aligns with conventional age notation in narratives.  
- ‚Äúat la escuela office‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúat the school office.‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Issue: dialect and clarity. Rationale: Translating ‚Äúla escuela‚Äù to ‚Äúthe school‚Äù uses standard terms and removes code-switching mid-sentence.  
- ‚ÄúSometimes I say things like ‚ÄòI have 15 years‚Äô because that‚Äôs how we say it in Spanish,‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúSometimes I say things like ‚ÄòI‚Äôm 15 years old‚Äô because in Spanish we literally say ‚ÄòI have 15 years,‚Äô‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Issue: grammar and clarity. Rationale: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm 15 years old‚Äù is the correct English equivalent. Placing the Spanish phrase in quotation clarifies its origin.  
- ‚ÄúIt be confusing switching back and forth,‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúIt can be confusing to switch back and forth,‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Issue: tense/formality. Rationale: ‚ÄúIt can be confusing‚Äù uses a standard modal construction instead of nonstandard ‚Äúbe.‚Äù  
- ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm learning to slow down and think in English first when needed, and also not be ashamed of speaking both.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm learning to slow down, think in English first when I need to, and not be ashamed of speaking both languages.‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Issue: parallel structure. Rationale: Adding ‚Äúlanguages‚Äù clarifies ‚Äúboth,‚Äù and ensuring each verb phrase follows the same pattern improves readability.

Structural Suggestions  
- Split the first sentence for clarity. Consider:  
  1) ‚ÄúWhen I was ten, my family and I moved to the U.S.‚Äù  
  2) ‚ÄúAt the school office, I used to translate for my parents.‚Äù

- Move the explanation of ‚ÄúI have 15 years‚Äù immediately after mentioning code-switching:  
  ‚Ä¢ This groups all examples of language mixing into one spot, making your narrative progression smoother.  
- Consider adding a brief concluding sentence on how these experiences shape you today, e.g.: ‚ÄúThat practice not only helped my parents but also made me more confident in both languages.‚Äù  
  ‚Ä¢ Provides a stronger wrap-up and reinforces your growth.

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add specific feelings or reactions (e.g., ‚ÄúI felt embarrassed when people laughed‚Äù or ‚ÄúI laughed along‚Äù) to deepen emotional engagement.  
- Include a transition word (however, although, even though) before ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm learning‚Ä¶‚Äù to strengthen connection between confusion and personal growth.  
- If space allows, give one concrete example of translating at school to illustrate your role and its impact.

Formatting Guidance

- Use standard paragraphing without extra line breaks for a personal-narrative paragraph.  
- Use straight quotation marks around spoken phrases: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm 15 years old.‚Äù  
- Maintain one-inch margins and a readable font (e.g., Times New Roman, 12 pt) for submission to a teacher.

This edit focuses on tightening your executive summary for clarity and impact. I‚Äôve guided you to:  
- Clarify the **value proposition** and **problem statement** up front  
- Use a consistent, confident tone without hype  
- Fix small grammar and punctuation issues  
- Restructure into clear sections (Value Proposition, Problem, Pilot Results, Growth Plan, Risks & Mitigation)  
- Format with H2/H3 headings, bullets, and bold key metrics  

Overall Feedback  
Your summary clearly presents the core idea and impressive pilot metrics. To sharpen its impact for small business owners, let‚Äôs:  
- Lead with a concise **value proposition**  
- State the **problem** in one punchy sentence  
- Combine pilot results into a tight bullet list for scannability  
- Sequence content in a logical flow (What, Why, How, Results, Next Steps)  
- Keep tone confident and direct, removing words that dilute authority (for example, ‚Äúsimple‚Äù or ‚Äúwhich we plan to‚Äù)  

Spelling Edits  
- ‚Äúads that works‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúads that work‚Äù  
  Rationale (grammar): Corrects subject‚Äìverb agreement  

Grammar Edits  
- Original: ‚Äúsmall shops don‚Äôt have time or money to run ads that works.‚Äù  
  Correction: ‚Äúsmall shops don‚Äôt have time or money to run ads that work.‚Äù  
  Issue (grammar): Subject‚Äìverb agreement  

- Original: ‚ÄúWith our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased 12% in 6 weeks, with 9 stores renewing for the next quarter.‚Äù  
  Correction: ‚ÄúIn our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased by 12% over six weeks; nine stores have already renewed for the next quarter.‚Äù  
  Issue (grammar/clarity): Avoid comma splice; spell out ‚Äúsix‚Äù‚Äîimproves readability  

- Original: ‚Äúbreak-even at 320 paying locations‚Äù  
  Correction: ‚Äúachieve break-even at 320 paying locations‚Äù  
  Issue (clarity): Adds verb to complete the thought  

- Original: ‚ÄúRisks include churn and notification fatigue which we plan to mitigate with controls.‚Äù  
  Correction: ‚ÄúRisks include churn and notification fatigue, which we plan to mitigate through specific controls.‚Äù  
  Issue (grammar/clarity): Adds missing comma and clarifies ‚Äúcontrols‚Äù  

Structural Suggestions  
- Reorder into clear subsections:  
  H2 Value Proposition ‚Üí H2 Problem ‚Üí H2 Pilot Results ‚Üí H2 Growth Plan ‚Üí H2 Risks & Mitigation  
  This creates a logical narrative arc from what you do to how you‚Äôll scale.  
- Under ‚ÄúPilot Results,‚Äù use bullets for each key metric (e.g., ‚Äú+12% foot traffic,‚Äù ‚Äú50% renewal rate‚Äù) so metrics stand out.  
- Combine redundant phrases (‚Äúusing geo-targeted notifications and simple onboarding‚Äù) into one succinct phrase under Value Proposition.  
- Expand ‚Äúcontrols‚Äù slightly (for example, ‚Äúfrequency caps‚Äù or ‚Äúopt-out options‚Äù) to show concrete planning.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add a brief example or testimonial from one pilot store to humanize the data.  
- Quantify cost savings or ROI if available (e.g., ‚Äúcost per new customer decreased by 20%‚Äù).  
- Insert a transition sentence before Risks to signal that you‚Äôre moving from results to caution points (e.g., ‚ÄúWhile results are promising, we recognize key risks‚Ä¶‚Äù).  

Formatting Guidance  
- Use H2 headings (e.g., ‚Äú## Pilot Results‚Äù) and H3 subheads for bullet groups.  
- Bold critical figures and terms (for example, **12%**, **Q3**, **break-even**).  
- Present metrics in bullet lists for quick scanning by busy owners.  
- Maintain consistent spacing (one blank line between sections).  
- If you include footnotes or references, use a simple superscript and list style at the end.

    "coverageText": "Overview  
This feedback focuses on turning your persuasive speech outline into a smooth, 5‚Äì6-minute presentation for your classmates. We‚Äôll refine grammar and transitions, strengthen the motivational but grounded tone, and reorganize content so each section flows logically. Finally, you‚Äôll get clear formatting guidance for your speaking notes, including cue words and spacing.

Overall Feedback  
‚Ä¢ You have a strong, relatable hook and a clear problem‚Äìsolution structure.  
‚Ä¢ The evidence section needs more concrete details and smoother transitions to keep your classmates engaged.  
‚Ä¢ Addressing the counterargument is effective but could use a transition phrase and brief explanation to strengthen your point.  
‚Ä¢ Your three-step solution is concise, but you can expand each step slightly to meet the time requirement and make it actionable.  
‚Ä¢ Close with a powerful call to action‚Äîspell out exactly what you want your peers to do over the next seven days.

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ No spelling errors found. (Spelling check) Your outline‚Äôs key words are all spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúScreen time going up; attention going down.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúScreen time is increasing, and attention spans are decreasing.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: grammar (subject‚Äìverb agreement) and clarity. Adding verbs makes it a complete sentence and keeps the parallel structure.  
‚Ä¢ ‚Äúgrades slipping, sleep shorter, I felt it last semester.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúGrades are slipping, sleep is shorter, and I felt these effects last semester.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: parallel structure and clarity. Use full verbs and consistent phrasing for each item.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúPhones are tools‚Äîyes, but tools shape us.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúPhones are tools, yes, but these tools shape us.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: punctuation. A comma after ‚Äútools‚Äù softens the break and improves flow.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúAsk audience to try it for 7 days.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Corrected: ‚ÄúAsk the audience to try these steps for seven days.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: clarity and style. Spell out ‚Äúseven‚Äù (style) and specify ‚Äúthese steps‚Äù so the call to action is clear.

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Hook ‚Üí Problem/Evidence: After your hook, add a one-sentence transition like, ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs why that matters to all of us.‚Äù This will guide listeners into the problem.  
‚Ä¢ Combine ‚ÄúProblem‚Äù and ‚ÄúEvidence‚Äù: Rather than separate bullets, narrate: ‚ÄúOver the last year, my average screen time shot up by two hours a day, my grades dipped from a B+ to a B‚Äì, and I was waking up exhausted.‚Äù This merges evidence and personal anecdote for impact.  
‚Ä¢ Counterargument placement: Introduce it with ‚ÄúNow, you might be thinking‚Ä¶‚Äù This sets up the objection before you refute it.  
‚Ä¢ Solution expansion: Label each step (‚ÄúStep 1: Switch to grayscale,‚Äù etc.), then add a brief ‚Äúwhy this works‚Äù sentence under each. That helps fill time and gives classmates context.  
‚Ä¢ Close with call to action: End with a clear challenge‚Äî‚ÄúWill you join me in regaining control of your attention? Let‚Äôs start today, for the next seven days.‚Äù This frames the ask as a group effort.

Opportunities for Improvement  
‚Ä¢ Add a brief data point or statistic (e.g., average teen screen time) to strengthen your evidence.  
‚Ä¢ Use a short personal story or visual image to make the problem relatable.  
‚Ä¢ Include a rhetorical question or quick audience poll (‚ÄúHow many of you check Instagram first thing?‚Äù) for engagement.  
‚Ä¢ Vary sentence length and tone‚Äîmix shorter, punchy lines with longer, explanatory ones to maintain interest.

Formatting Guidance  
‚Ä¢ Headings: Label each main section in your notes‚ÄîHOOK, PROBLEM, EVIDENCE, COUNTERARGUMENT, SOLUTION, CALL TO ACTION.  
‚Ä¢ Cue words: Insert [PAUSE] after your hook, [EMPHASIZE] before a key fact, [LOOK AROUND] when engaging classmates.  
‚Ä¢ Spacing: Leave one line blank between sections so you can turn pages without losing your place.  
‚Ä¢ Indentation: Use bullet points for sub-ideas under each heading, and number your three steps clearly.  
‚Ä¢ Timing notes: In the margin, jot time targets (e.g., ‚Äú1 min for Hook,‚Äù ‚Äú2 min for Evidence‚Äù) to stay within 5‚Äì6 minutes.

Overall Feedback  
‚Ä¢ Chronology and tense consistency: Right now, the narrative shifts between present and past tense and jumps around in time. Converting everything to the past tense and arranging the sentences to follow the actual sequence of events will make the story flow more smoothly for your English class.  
‚Ä¢ Descriptive clarity: A few concrete details‚Äîlike how the ice looked or how physical therapy felt‚Äîwill bring your reflection to life. Short, sensory phrases can deepen the reader‚Äôs connection.  
‚Ä¢ Sentence variety: You open several sentences with ‚ÄúI.‚Äù Varying your sentence openings and combining some shorter sentences can improve rhythm and keep the reader engaged.  

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ No spelling errors were detected in the provided text. All words conform to standard American English spelling.

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúI am limping down the stairs last winter when the ice was invisible, and then I fell.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Suggestion: Change to ‚ÄúI was limping down the stairs last winter when invisible ice sent me tumbling.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: tense consistency (grammar) and clarity (style). Converting ‚Äúam limping‚Äù to ‚Äúwas limping‚Äù keeps past tense consistent, and restructuring combines two actions for smoother flow.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúLater, in physical therapy, I learn patience I didn‚Äôt know I had.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Suggestion: Change ‚Äúlearn‚Äù to ‚Äúlearned.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: tense consistency (grammar). Past tense ‚Äúlearned‚Äù matches the timeline.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúBy spring I was jogging, then I am running.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Suggestion: Change ‚Äúthen I am running‚Äù to ‚Äúthen I was running.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: tense consistency (grammar). Unifying past tense preserves the retrospective narrative.  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe day I broke my ankle is the day I decided to join track, which doesn‚Äôt make sense until I explain.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Suggestion: Change ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt‚Äù to ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt,‚Äù or consider rephrasing to ‚Äúmay not make sense yet.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: tense consistency (grammar) and tone (clarity). ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt‚Äù matches past tense; ‚Äúyet‚Äù softens the transition.  

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Open with the fall, then explain the decision:  
  ‚Äì Move ‚ÄúThe day I broke my ankle‚Ä¶‚Äù after your vivid description of slipping on ice. This anchors the reader in the moment before revealing your decision to join track.  
‚Ä¢ Group the rehabilitation details into one paragraph:

‚Ä¢ Conclude with a reflective summary:  
  ‚Äì After ‚ÄúJoining track taught me‚Ä¶,‚Äù add a brief reflection sentence that ties back to hope or future goals. This bookends your narrative with the reflective, hopeful tone you want.  

Opportunities for Improvement

‚Ä¢ Vary sentence length: Mix one- or two-word exclamations (‚ÄúOuch!‚Äù) or questions (‚ÄúCould I do this?‚Äù) with longer, flowing sentences for emphasis.  
‚Ä¢ Strengthen transitions: Use words like ‚Äúafter,‚Äù ‚Äúsoon,‚Äù or ‚Äúas a result‚Äù to show cause and effect between injury, therapy, and joining track.  

Formatting Guidance

Based on your goals‚Äîmaking the email polite and clear, fixing grammar and formatting, and suggesting a strong professional structure‚ÄîI‚Äôve focused on clarity, formality, and concise phrasing appropriate for a college-level email to a professor. Key areas include hyphenation, date and time formatting, paragraph division, and a more specific subject line.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft is concise and respectful, which fits your tone preference. To increase clarity and formality, I recommend:
‚Ä¢ Hyphenating compound modifiers and spelling out months in full.  
‚Ä¢ Splitting the body into two short paragraphs (context then request) for better flow.  
‚Ä¢ Adding a brief opening line (e.g., ‚ÄúI hope you are well‚Äù) to soften the request.  
‚Ä¢ Refining the subject line to state the exact request (‚Äú48-Hour Extension‚Äù).  

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ None detected ‚Äì all words are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ Original: ‚ÄúI am requesting a 48 hour extension for the research brief due Sept 28.‚Äù  
  Correction: ‚ÄúI am requesting a 48-hour extension for the research brief due September 28.‚Äù  
  Reasoning: Hyphenate the compound adjective ‚Äú48-hour‚Äù (grammar) and spell out the month for formality (style).

‚Ä¢ Original: ‚ÄúIf approved, I will submit by Sept 30 at 11:59pm.‚Äù  
  Correction: ‚ÄúIf approved, I will submit it by September 30 at 11:59 p.m.‚Äù  
  Reasoning: Add the pronoun ‚Äúit‚Äù for clarity (grammar), spell out the month (style), and format time with periods and a space before ‚Äúp.m.‚Äù (style/consistency).

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Add a brief opener: Insert ‚ÄúI hope you are well.‚Äù before stating your request. This enhances tone and rapport.  
‚Ä¢ Divide the body into two paragraphs:  
  ‚Äì Paragraph 1: Context (‚ÄúI have completed most of the reading, but I need extra time‚Ä¶‚Äù)  
  ‚Äì Paragraph 2: Request and deadline (‚ÄúWould you please grant me‚Ä¶‚Äù + specify new date/time).  
  This separation improves readability and highlights the request.  
‚Ä¢ Refine the subject line: Change it to ‚ÄúRequest for 48-Hour Extension on Research Brief Due September 28.‚Äù A precise subject helps your professor immediately know what you need.

Opportunities for Improvement  
‚Ä¢ Consider adding a one-sentence expression of gratitude in advance (‚ÄúI appreciate your understanding and support.‚Äù) to strengthen politeness.  
‚Ä¢ Use ‚Äúwould you please‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúI am requesting‚Äù to soften the tone.  
‚Ä¢ Confirm receipt: you might add, ‚ÄúPlease let me know if this is acceptable.‚Äù to invite a reply.

Formatting Guidance  
‚Ä¢ Subject Line: Make it action-oriented and specific (see Structural Suggestions).  
‚Ä¢ Greeting: ‚ÄúDear Professor Ahmed,‚Äù is slightly more formal than ‚ÄúHi Professor Ahmed,‚Äù but either is acceptable.  
‚Ä¢ Opening Line: A brief pleasantry (‚ÄúI hope you‚Äôre doing well.‚Äù).

Overall Feedback  
Your paragraph effectively highlights how the storm scene establishes tension and foreshadows the film‚Äôs survival theme. To sharpen it for a blog audience, I recommend:  
- Naming or specifying ‚Äúthe commander‚Äù for clarity  
- Maintaining present-tense consistency throughout

Grammar Edits

‚Ä¢ ‚Äúit put us in chaos‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúit puts the audience in chaos.‚Äù  
  Issue: verb tense consistency and pronoun clarity. Explanation: ‚ÄúPuts‚Äù keeps present tense, and ‚Äúthe audience‚Äù is more formal than ‚Äúus.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe sound mix is loud and harsh, it put us in chaos.‚Äù ‚Üí two sentences or semicolon:  
   ‚ÄúThe sound mix is loud and harsh; it puts the audience in chaos.‚Äù  
  Issue: comma splice. Explanation: A semicolon or period correctly separates two independent clauses.  
‚Ä¢ ‚Äúgroup decision under pressure‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúgroup decision-making under pressure‚Äù  
  Issue: style and clarity. Explanation: The hyphenated phrase ‚Äúdecision-making‚Äù more precisely names the process.

Structural Suggestions  
‚Ä¢ Combine context and analysis for smoother flow. For example, merge your first two sentences:  
  Original: ‚ÄúIn the opening of *The Martian*, the storm scene shows how group decision under pressure can go wrong. Commander makes fast call and it seems rational‚Ä¶‚Äù  
  Suggested: ‚ÄúIn the opening of *The Martian*, a dust storm forces the crew‚Äôs commander to order an emergency evacuation‚Äîan ostensibly rational call that, through tight framing on worried faces, reveals the flaws of group decision-making under pressure.‚Äù  
  How it helps: Condenses setup and analysis into one dynamic sentence, making your writing more concise.

  ‚ÄúThis early sequence not only immerses viewers in chaos but also foreshadows the core struggle of *The Martian*: balancing split-second judgments with meticulous planning for survival.‚Äù

Opportunities for Improvement

This edit focuses on tightening punctuation and capitalization, clarifying and condensing phrasing, and applying AP style for a community profile article in a school newspaper. We‚Äôll preserve Ms. Johnson‚Äôs quotes verbatim, respect the portrayal of all students, and suggest structural tweaks and formatting tips for smooth reading and clear attribution.

Overall Feedback  
‚Ä¢ The profile provides a warm, inclusive snapshot of the coding club, but a few sentences run together or use comma splices. Breaking them into shorter, clearer statements will improve flow.  
‚Ä¢ Applying AP style will standardize titles, numbers, and quotation formatting.  
‚Ä¢ Adding brief context‚Äîsuch as the school‚Äôs name or the club‚Äôs size‚Äîand paragraph breaks will give readers landmarks and make the article more engaging.

Spelling Edits  
‚Ä¢ No misspellings were found in the submitted text.

Grammar Edits  
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúMs. Johnson, a veteran and math teacher, started the after-school coding club to help students who felt left out of tech.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: ‚Äúmath teacher‚Äù (style)  
  ‚Äì Correction: ‚Äúmathematics teacher‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Reason: AP style prefers ‚Äúmathematics‚Äù in formal titles (style).

‚Ä¢ ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚ÄòEverybody can learn to code,‚Äô she said, ‚Äòwe just need a place to try and fail safely.‚Äô‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: run-on quotation and lowercase after comma (punctuation, grammar)  
  ‚Äì Correction: ‚Äú‚ÄòEverybody can learn to code,‚Äô she said. ‚ÄòWe just need a place to try and fail safely.‚Äô‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Reason: Separate into two sentences for clarity; capitalize ‚ÄúWe‚Äù per standard sentence rules (AP style).

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThe club has students from different backgrounds and abilities and they pair up to solve small problems.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: missing comma or conjunction (grammar)  
  ‚Äì Correction: ‚ÄúThe club has students from different backgrounds and abilities, and they pair up to solve small problems.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Reason: Add comma before ‚Äúand‚Äù linking two independent clauses (comma use).

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúLast week they built an app that shows bus schedules, it was buggy but then they fixed it together.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Issue: comma splice (grammar)  
  ‚Äì Correction: ‚ÄúLast week, they built an app that shows bus schedules. It was buggy, but they fixed it together.‚Äù  
  ‚Äì Reason: Split into two sentences to avoid comma splice; add comma before ‚Äúbut‚Äù in a compound sentence.

Structural Suggestions  
1. Lead with context: Begin with the school name and number of club members.  
   ‚Äì Example: ‚ÄúAt Lincoln High School, 15 students come together every Wednesday after class‚Ä¶‚Äù  
   ‚Äì Improves reader orientation and stakes.  
2. Break into paragraphs:  
   ‚Äì Paragraph 1: Introduction of Ms. Johnson and club purpose.  
   ‚Äì Paragraph 2: Include her quote about coding.

3. Close with impact: Add a final quote or statistic about student success or upcoming showcase.

Opportunities for Improvement  
‚Ä¢ Add specific student voices or a short quote (with permission) to illustrate ‚Äúdifferent backgrounds.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ Use transition words (‚ÄúFor example,‚Äù ‚ÄúAs a result,‚Äù ‚ÄúNext‚Äù) for smoother connections between ideas.  
‚Ä¢ Mention the club‚Äôs meeting time or location for practical value to readers.

Formatting Guidance  
‚Ä¢ AP style for titles: Use ‚ÄúMs. Johnson‚Äù on first reference without academic degrees; thereafter use ‚ÄúJohnson.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ Numbers: Spell out numbers under 10 (e.g., ‚Äúfive students‚Äù), use numerals for 10 and above.

‚Ä¢ Paragraphing: Keep each main idea in its own paragraph.  
‚Ä¢ Dates/times: Write as ‚Äú4 p.m. Tuesdays‚Äù (lowercase abbreviations, periods in a.m./p.m.).

Would you like me to produce a revised version of your text incorporating these edits? Do you have any additional questions or areas you‚Äôd like more guidance on?",

text: Growing up as a first-generation Mexican American, I often translated bank forms for my parents and tried to make sense of bills with unfamiliar words. At first, I felt small in those offices, like I was pretending to be older. Over time, I realized I was learning a language of responsibility. When my mom‚Äôs small catering business almost closed during the pandemic, I made flyers, wrote emails, and built a simple website on my cracked phone. It wasn‚Äôt perfect, but it worked, and we kept going. This taught me how community isn‚Äôt a slogan; it‚Äôs people showing up for each other. I still worry about sounding ‚Äúright,‚Äù but I‚Äôve learned to ask questions and keep trying even when I‚Äôm unsure. College, to me, is a place to grow that force of trying into something that can help others, especially families navigating systems that pretend to be simple.

shoes unlaced, the gravel keeps my secrets.

and they don‚Äôt answer (they never did)
but the leaves clap anyway, a small stadium.
tomorrow is a folded map in my pocket
that I forgot to unfold.

text: Title: How I Stopped Procrastinating By Doing Less
Intro: I used to think I need more apps to fix my procrastination. Turns out, I needed less‚Äîless options, less tabs, less guilt.
## Tip 1: Make a Not-To-Do List
This is not negative! It focuses your attention on what you should ignore. For example, checking Twitter every 10 minutes is a bad loop I had.
## Tip 2: Set "good enough" deadlines
Perfectionism is a trap. If you schedule shorter blocks and accept B+ work at first, you will move faster.
## Conclusion
Doing less is surprisingly brave. You will feel weird at first, but then free.
